1. Bob Katter, an outspoken MP, has been criticized for potentially inciting a race row with his comments about the Queensland Government's view of Billy Gordon, an embattled MP accused of domestic violence and withholding his criminal past from the Premier.
2. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent and has experienced racism from major parties, empathized with Gordon and accused the government of seeing him as 'a little black puppet on a string,' suggesting they expected Gordon to resign following the allegations.
3. Despite the controversy, Gordon decided to remain in the Queensland parliament as an independent, which has thrown the government into disarray due to its slim majority.
4. Katter questioned why it was assumed Gordon would resign, referencing past federal cases where similar situations did not lead to resignations.
5. Social media users have criticized Katter's choice of words, with some suggesting there would be more outrage if a figure like former Prime Minister Tony Abbott had used such terminology.
6. Katter defended his statement, explaining that he used the term 'black puppet' to highlight what he perceives as racial overtones in the government's attitude towards Gordon, drawing on his own experiences with racism as a dark-skinned person from Cloncurry.
7. Katter also cited the examples of federal MPs Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott, who he believes became government puppets and sacrificed their independence, but he assured that Gordon would not follow that path.

19-year-old Dayna Dobias from Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy and has faced bullying and stereotypes due to her disability. Despite these challenges, she is determined to change perceptions and inspire others through her passion for dance. Dayna creates videos of herself dancing to show that her condition does not define her abilities or her identity. She aims to counteract the stereotypes that people with disabilities face, emphasizing that while she may do things differently, she should not be treated differently.

Dayna's videos, including one set to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," are intended to entertain, inspire, and encourage people to think before they judge. She wants to be seen as just one of us, rather than being defined by her disability. Her motivation extends beyond dance as she has taken up motivational speaking at local schools in the Chicago area, spreading her message of inclusivity and positivity. Despite initial concerns from doctors about her ability to walk, Dayna not only walks but also dances, drives, and attends college, living a life similar to any other 19-year-old. Her goal is to turn negativity into positivity and to raise awareness and smiles through her dancing and speaking engagements.

1. Orlando City, an MLS team with a significant Latin-American fanbase, has shown interest in Manchester United's Javier Hernandez.
2. Hernandez, a Mexican international, has struggled during his loan at Real Madrid and is attracting interest from eight European clubs in addition to Orlando City.
3. Manchester United is willing to sell Hernandez for approximately £8 million, with Premier League clubs Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, and Everton, as well as European clubs Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, all expressing interest.
4. Hernandez has one year remaining on his contract with Manchester United.
5. Manchester United has made a new contract offer to 19-year-old prospect Andreas Pereira after he rejected their initial offer.
6. Pereira, who was on the bench for United's match against Aston Villa, has drawn interest from European clubs including Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord.

A group of at least three individuals doused a white Dodge Charger with gasoline and set it on fire at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am on Saturday. The driver of the car, who remains unidentified, reported that he had been involved in an argument with the suspects while filling up his car. Despite there being two passengers in the vehicle at the time, all occupants escaped unharmed. However, the car was completely destroyed by the fire. The driver's grandmother stated that the suspects attempted to carjack her grandson before setting the car alight, an account supported by surveillance video that captured the incident. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is treating the case as arson, and the suspects are still at large. No further details on the suspects or their motives have been provided.

A chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his license after being accused of engaging in inappropriate conduct with patients. The Iowa Board of Chiropractic reported that Manuel admitted to accepting sexual favors in exchange for his services and conducting exorcisms on patients. He has agreed not to seek reinstatement of his license for a minimum of 10 years. Despite these allegations, Manuel has received high patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. Additionally, he advised patients to cease taking medications he had prescribed. Manuel's former practice confirmed he had not worked there for a while, and his listed practice address appears to be a residential home in the small agricultural town of Lamoni. The summary of patient reviews on HealthGrades.com, although limited to three responses, showed a perfect five-star rating for patient satisfaction.

A Russian SU-27 Flanker intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner" on Tuesday. The incident occurred in international airspace north of Poland, and the U.S. crew reported the Russian pilot's actions as unsafe due to aggressive maneuvers at high speed and close proximity. The Pentagon, through spokesman Mark Wright, stated that they would file a complaint with Russia via diplomatic channels. Russia's Defense Ministry spokesman, Maj. Gen. Igor Konashenkov, countered by saying the U.S. plane was approaching the Russian border with its transponder off, and the Russian jet identified the aircraft by flying around it several times. However, the U.S. European Command refuted the claim about the transponder being off. This is not an isolated event; a similar incident occurred a year prior over the Sea of Okhotsk, which was also followed by a U.S. complaint to Russia. Such encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft are not uncommon in Northern Europe and the area between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

A sniper rifle belonging to an FBI agent was stolen from the agent's vehicle in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City. The rifle, which was secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains to a truck safe, was taken by breaking the car's rear right passenger-side window. The thief likely used another vehicle to pull the case through the window, as evidenced by the damage to the window frame and the discovery of skid marks and rope pieces near the scene. The theft occurred on March 27, just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. Along with the rifle, the agent's gear bag, backpack, and some personal items were also stolen. Some of the agent's belongings were later found at a nearby Residence Inn, but the rifle remains missing. The hotel where the theft took place lacks surveillance cameras, and it is unknown if the agent's car was specifically targeted. The rifle's serial number has been entered into a national crime database, and the Secret Service was informed of the theft prior to Obama's visit, though it is unclear if the incident affected security measures. The hotel is located near the Salt Lake City airport and the state's FBI office.

71-year-old Luigi Costa is accused of murdering his elderly neighbour, Terrence Freebody, in July 2012 in Red Hill, Canberra. The attack involved stomping on the victim's head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa likely suffered from dementia and alcohol abuse, which affected his mental state before and during the incident. Evidence of Costa's fluctuating mood and confused state included his erratic triple 0 calls and a trail of faeces leading to the toilet where he was found. Professor Mullen dismissed the prosecution's suggestion that Costa was feigning memory issues, stating that it was probable Costa had been suffering from dementia for some time. The jury's ability to return a verdict of not guilty hinges on whether they are convinced of Costa's compromised mental state at the time of the attack.

1. Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty in their match against Burnley, which Barkley missed.
2. The penalty was awarded in the 10th minute for a foul on Aaron Lennon by David Jones.
3. Barkley took the penalty instead of Leighton Baines, who has a strong record of 15 successful penalties out of 16 attempts in the Premier League.
4. There was no dispute between Barkley and Baines over the penalty, unlike a previous incident in January when Kevin Mirallas took a penalty from Baines and missed against West Brom.
5. Martinez stated that Barkley was entitled to take the penalty and that he encourages players to step up if they feel confident in the moment.
6. Barkley's penalty was saved by Burnley's goalkeeper Tom Heaton.
7. Despite the missed penalty, Everton won the match 1-0 with a goal from Mirallas after 29 minutes.
8. Martinez expressed his support for players taking responsibility in big moments and indicated that Baines was supportive of Barkley taking the penalty.

A murder-suicide appears to have taken place on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico, according to Holland America Line. Two passengers were found deceased in their stateroom by the cleaning staff after they knocked on the cabin's door. The incident occurred on Thursday at 11:30 a.m., and the cabin was promptly secured with authorities, including the FBI, notified. The cruise ship had departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and was docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico, at the time of the discovery. Holland America Line is fully cooperating with the investigation, and the FBI is currently on the scene conducting an inquiry to determine the official cause of the deaths.

Patrick Kluivert, former Dutch forward and assistant coach, has successfully led the Curacao national team to the second round of CONCACAF World Cup qualifying for the 2018 tournament. Curacao secured their advancement with a 2-2 draw against Montserrat in the second leg, resulting in a 4-3 aggregate win after also winning the first leg 2-1. Kluivert, who has Curacaoan heritage, was instrumental in the team's progression, with a crucial goal scored by substitute Charlton Vicento in the 87th minute to avoid extra time. Curacao will next face Cuba in the second qualifying round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert's coaching achievement follows his previous experience as an assistant coach at the 2014 World Cup under Louis van Gaal, and his own playing career where he reached the semi-finals of the 1998 World Cup.

Esteban Cambiasso, a seasoned footballer with a history of success in European competitions, considers helping Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League as a significant achievement, akin to winning a trophy. Despite Leicester's challenging position at the bottom of the table with eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic about the team's chances of survival. His impressive career includes winning 15 trophies with Inter Milan, as well as titles with River Plate and Real Madrid. Cambiasso, who joined Leicester on a one-year deal after a decade at Inter, has become a vital player for the Foxes. He reflects on his time in England, expressing happiness with his personal life and suggesting he might extend his stay at Leicester beyond the current season. His determination and belief in his team's ability to remain in the Premier League underscore his commitment to the club's fight against relegation.

A 23-year-old mother, identified as Gemma, is facing the possibility of being banned from seeing her two young children by her own mother, Debbie. Gemma has two children under five with different fathers and gave them to Debbie when they were just four months old. Debbie is considering this action due to Gemma's refusal to stop her excessive drinking, partying, and use of the legal high MKat. Additionally, Debbie suspects Gemma of stealing, including an iPad from one of the children to fund her lifestyle. Although Gemma denies stealing the iPad, she has admitted to stealing from her mother in the past. Debbie has been the primary caregiver for the children since their infancy, after social services threatened to intervene. Gemma's behavior has been problematic since she was a teenager, with early drinking and underage sex. Debbie, who appeared with Gemma on The Jeremy Kyle Show, is now prepared to cut off contact between Gemma and the children, as she cannot trust her not to steal from them. The children, who refer to Debbie as "mum," have been primarily raised by her. Debbie expresses deep concern for her grandchildren's well-being and is upset by Gemma's lack of care and responsibility towards them.

The passage describes the controversy surrounding the opening goal scored by Chelsea's Eden Hazard against Manchester United at Stamford Bridge. During the build-up to the goal, Chelsea captain John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on United's striker Radamel Falcao, which led to Falcao falling to the ground and losing possession. Cesc Fabregas collected the loose ball and initiated the move that resulted in Hazard's goal. Despite the quality of the goal, the Sky Sports pundits—Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness—unanimously agreed during half-time that Terry's challenge should have been penalized as a foul. Souness pointed out that Terry's forearm smash and elbow contact to the back of Falcao's head was a clear foul, while Henry expressed empathy for Falcao, stating he would have wanted a foul called in that situation. Redknapp acknowledged that although Falcao could have remained upright, Terry's challenge was still a foul. The pundits' consensus was that the referee should have stopped play for Terry's aggressive tackle.

A tour bus carrying Hillary Scott, a singer from the band Lady Antebellum, caught fire on a Texas freeway. The incident occurred on Interstate 30 near Dallas, and bystander Michael Barnett captured and uploaded dramatic footage of the burning bus to CNN iReport. Although the fire was extensive, everyone on board, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, was safely evacuated. The fire started after a rear tire blowout, and the bus was engulfed in flames after the evacuation. Scott expressed gratitude on Instagram for their safety and for those who helped extinguish the fire. She also noted that her Bible was the only item unscathed in the back lounge of the bus. The other band members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus at the time. Despite the incident, Lady Antebellum is still scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

1. Dr. Adrian Quarterman, a scientist from Dundee University, is developing a space laser system that could potentially heat homes by converting sunlight into energy using satellites equipped with mirrors and semiconductors.
2. This technology would make solar power viable in places like Scotland and could quickly restore power in disaster-stricken areas.
3. The system works by firing laser beams at solar panels on Earth to enhance the energy they collect.
4. Initial tests in Scotland have been successful, and further trials are planned for Portugal.
5. Unlike the destructive lasers depicted in science fiction and movies, these space lasers are not powerful enough to cause harm, with Dr. Quarterman emphasizing they would not be able to blind a pigeon.
6. There is a separate proposal by researchers at the Riken research institute in Tokyo to attach a laser system to the International Space Station aimed at clearing space debris by pushing it into Earth's atmosphere to burn up.
7. The Tokyo system's laser would target small pieces of debris up to 62 miles away and, like Dr. Quarterman's lasers, would not be powerful enough to be used as a weapon.
8. Despite the peaceful intentions, Dr. Quarterman acknowledges there may be concerns about who controls such satellite-based laser systems.

54-year-old Stephen Munden, a convicted paedophile with a history of sexual offenses against young girls, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. He was last seen leaving the hospital on Tuesday at 6:15 pm. Munden, who is described as 5ft 8ins tall, heavy build, with dark hair, may have shaved his beard and is known to have a "fanatical obsession" with small girls. He was detained under the Mental Health Act after sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus in view of her mother and grandmother. Munden had also admitted to ten unrelated offenses of possessing or attempting to possess indecent images of children. He was convicted and sentenced for these offenses and was being held at the private facility under a hospital order. The court heard that he had children's clothes, books, and dolls at his home. Despite Munden's claim that the touching was accidental, the judge considered the transition from non-contact to contact offenses significant and made him subject to a hospital order. Munden is autistic and suffers from mild learning difficulties. The police have launched a manhunt to locate him, urging the public to report any sightings immediately due to the urgency of his condition and the potential risk he poses.

1. Donald Sterling, former owner of the NBA's Los Angeles Clippers, was embroiled in a scandal after his racist remarks were made public.
2. V. Stiviano, Sterling's former female companion, was ordered by a Los Angeles judge to repay over $2.6 million in gifts to Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, following a lawsuit.
3. Shelly Sterling accused Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men and claimed that Donald Sterling used the couple's money to buy Stiviano expensive gifts, including luxury cars and a $1.8 million duplex.
4. Stiviano argued that there was nothing wrong with receiving gifts from Donald Sterling and denied taking advantage of him.
5. The court's decision in favor of Shelly Sterling was seen as a victory for the Sterling family and set a precedent for recovering damages from recipients of such gifts in similar situations.
6. The gifts in question ranged from high-end items like cars to more mundane items such as an Easter bunny costume, a blender, and lingerie.
7. Donald Sterling's downfall was precipitated by an audio recording of him criticizing Stiviano for associating with African-Americans and instructing her not to post photos with them on social media, including one with Magic Johnson.
8. As a result of the scandal, the NBA's Commissioner Adam Silver banned Sterling from the league, fined him $2.5 million, and facilitated the termination of his ownership rights in the Clippers franchise.

Thierry Henry has expressed his dissatisfaction with Arsenal's transfer strategy, stating that the club needs to acquire four high-quality players to compete for the Premier League title. He specifically mentioned the need for a goalkeeper, a center back, a defensive midfielder, and a top-tier striker. Henry's comments came after Arsenal's scoreless draw against Chelsea. He also singled out Olivier Giroud, suggesting that Arsenal's chances of winning the league would be limited if Giroud remains the primary striker, despite Giroud's 14 league goals that season. Henry compared Arsenal's situation to Chelsea's, noting that Chelsea's purchases of players like Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa significantly improved their team and put them in a position to win the league. Arsenal, at the time of Henry's comments, was third in the Premier League, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand. Henry emphasized the importance of a competitive squad to win the league and implied that Arsenal's current squad lacks the necessary depth and quality.

A young woman has testified in Sydney's District Court about the severe impact of years of sexual abuse by Maurice Van Ryn, the former Bega Cheese boss. Van Ryn has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim expressed fear for her future relationships and described how the abuse has affected her mentally and emotionally, leading to depression, self-harm, and attempted suicide. She only spoke out about the abuse after learning of Van Ryn's arrest. Despite her suffering, she worries about people finding out and is concerned about Van Ryn's potential release and its impact on her interactions with men. The court hearing is ongoing, and support for those affected by similar issues is available through organizations like Lifeline. Comments on the article are currently not being accepted.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old midfielder for Arsenal, has expressed that he is feeling increasingly better as he nears a return to the field after a lengthy absence due to a serious knee injury. Gnabry had shown promise during the previous season but has not played for Arsenal's first team since the Champions League match against Bayern Munich in March 2014. After a year-long hiatus, he played a full 90 minutes for the Arsenal Under 21s against Reading, signaling his recovery from the injury. The German Under-21 international is optimistic about his progress and is looking forward to future games, having overcome his injury concerns.

23-year-old accountant Jacob Phillips died after falling down a 70ft cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while attempting to evade a taxi fare. After a night out in Cardiff with friends, Phillips and his companions, Padraig Crowley and Rory Robinson, took a taxi to Penarth but did not have enough money to pay for the ride. They planned to use an ATM, but instead, they fled from the taxi. Phillips ran in a different direction from his friends and, in the dark, jumped over a fence, leading to his fatal fall. The incident occurred in December, and Phillips' body was found the following day by a dog walker at the base of the cliff. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, was unaware of the danger and would not have left Phillips if he had known their location. The coroner, Andrew Barkley, concluded that Phillips' death was accidental, noting that he likely became disoriented in the dark and was unaware of the cliff's proximity. Phillips, a University of Birmingham graduate, was working for Pretty Green, a clothing label owned by Liam Gallagher, and had returned to Wales for Christmas to stay with his mother in Cowbridge.

Last summer, thousands of holidaymakers experienced significant delays in receiving their passports, leading to a fiasco where many had to pay extra for expedited service or missed their trips altogether. Despite the chaos, which saw a backlog of over half a million passports, the passport agency reported a profit of £42 million. Managers at the agency received bonuses up to £3,500, while the majority of affected travelers received no compensation.

The Home Affairs Committee, chaired by Keith Vaz, called for compensation for the affected families, but the government refused, fearing it would set a precedent. Between April of the previous year and January of the following year, only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, a negligible increase from the 2,077 approved the year before. The total compensation paid out was £203,066, with an average payout of £92.68. The Passport Office was unable to provide the number of rejected claims due to a failure in their customer complaint database.

The government's decision to not offer blanket refunds meant that many who paid extra or missed trips did not receive any financial reimbursement. For example, Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham lost nearly £1,500 on a trip to Morocco where Bean had planned to propose, despite applying for their passports ten weeks in advance and paying for an upgrade. The Passport Office's financial surplus during this period was £42.3 million, and in the previous fiscal year, managers received a total of £1.8 million in bonuses.

A unique 1930s timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, is for sale, featuring original fixtures and decor from the era. This semi-detached property, with a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000, includes stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and retro food tins. The home's interior is a collector's dream, with an unmodified bathroom and kitchen, wood-panelled hallway, and vintage cupboards. Notable features include the mint green and black bathroom with original tiles and fixtures, a wood-panelled hall with ship-depicting stained glass, and living room windows adorned with coats of arms. The kitchen retains its original 1930s cupboards, an open-face brick fireplace, and a dated sink. Despite some modernizations like double glazing, the house's potential renovation costs may deter developers. Auction House director David Beddoe suggests it could be an ideal family home for antique enthusiasts. The property will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers behind Alex Smith. He took over as the starting quarterback during the 2012 season after Smith sustained a concussion. Kaepernick continued as the starter for the remainder of the season and led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl since 1994, where they were ultimately defeated by the Baltimore Ravens.

1997 American comedy-drama film "Soul Food" was produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and was released by Fox 2000 Pictures. The film explores the importance of family traditions and togetherness through the lens of an African-American family from Chicago, as they struggle to keep their family ties strong after the matriarch suffers a stroke. The story unfolds over a year of Sunday dinners, highlighting the challenges and triumphs of the Joseph family, with the meals serving as a symbol of their unity and cultural heritage. The film touches on themes of love, loss, and the strength of familial bonds, and it features an ensemble cast including Vanessa Williams, Vivica A. Fox, Nia Long, and Michael Beach. "Soul Food" was well-received for its portrayal of a close-knit family and its celebration of African-American culture, and it has since become a classic in the genre of family dramas.

1. Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and lived there during her early years before relocating to Texas and eventually to San Francisco.
2. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile-long freeway situated in Hudson County, New Jersey, United States.

8. "Everyday Robots" also included samples of Lord Buckley's rants.

Sheikh Ali Salman, the leader of al-Wefaq, emphasized the need for the Bahraini government to offer concrete solutions and demonstrate willingness for meaningful national dialogue. The passage provides a summary of the life and achievements of Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and early-music movement exponent, who passed away in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. His funeral will be private, with a public memorial service to be announced later. Hogwood was celebrated for his work with numerous prestigious orchestras worldwide. He established the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, leading the ensemble across six continents for three decades and producing over 200 CDs, notably the first complete Mozart symphonies cycle on period instruments. His acclaimed recordings include a 1980 rendition of Handel's Messiah, which was recognized as one of the greatest recordings by BBC Music Magazine.

Hogwood's musical education included studies with notable figures such as Rafael Puyana, Mary Potts, Zuzana Ruzickova, and Gustav Leonhardt at Cambridge University. He began his career as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and was a founding member of the Early Music Consort of London. He held significant positions, including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and the Handel and Haydn Society in Boston, and served as a tutor at Harvard University, an honorary professor at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University.

Tributes to Hogwood highlighted his generosity, his role as a pioneer in historically informed performance, and his influence on the development of the AAM after his directorship. His successor, Richard Egarr, expressed deep sadness and acknowledged Hogwood's significant legacy. Soprano Dame Emma Kirkby and David Thomas from Trinity Laban Conservatoire also praised Hogwood's academic prowess, his ability to let music speak for itself, and his genial personality.

1. In the year leading up to March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, a decrease of five from the previous year and the lowest number since 1976. This figure represents a significant decline compared to nine years prior.

1. Mr Abbott stated that to prevent deaths at sea, the Australian government's policy is to "stop the boats" by detaining migrants attempting to reach Australia by boat and sending them to offshore processing camps for resettlement elsewhere.

1. The US has suspended talks with Russia regarding the cessation of hostilities in Syria, blaming Russia and the Syrian government for escalating attacks on civilians, particularly in Aleppo.

The passage discusses a report by think tank Policy Exchange, which proposes selling high-value vacant social homes to fund the construction of new social housing. The report suggests that this could raise £4.5 billion annually, enough to build between 80,000 to 170,000 social homes, potentially the largest social house building program since the 1970s. Policy Exchange's director, Neil O'Brien, argues that while social housing would still exist in expensive areas, there would be less of it, and that no one has the right to live in the most expensive parts of town. He estimates that the scheme could reduce the social housing waiting list by about 500,000.

Downing Street supports the report, emphasizing that councils already have the option to sell high-value housing to invest in more social housing. The government believes this could help address the growing waiting list for social housing.

However, the Labour Party opposes the idea, stating that the coalition's policies are exacerbating the housing crisis. Shadow housing minister Jack Dromey suggests using a bank bonus tax to fund affordable housing and stimulate the construction industry.

The report defines expensive social housing as properties worth more than the regional average, which accounts for 21.8% of the UK's total social housing stock. Policy Exchange estimates that selling 3.5% of the total stock that becomes vacant each year could raise £5.5 billion, or £4.5 billion after debt repayment.

Critics of the proposal worry that it would lead to the displacement of low-income families from affluent areas, creating segregated communities. The National Housing Federation and Labour MP Karen Buck express concerns about the social consequences of such a policy.

In contrast, Housing Minister Grant Shapps supports the sell-off, citing the government's investment in affordable housing and the introduction of fixed-term tenancies to prioritize those in greatest need.

In summary, the passage outlines Policy Exchange's proposal to sell vacant high-value social homes to fund new social housing construction, with support from the government and opposition from the Labour Party and housing organizations, who are concerned about the social impact of the policy.

25-year-old Gareth Colfer-Williams from Swansea, the epicenter of a measles outbreak with 942 cases, died last week. 1. Cuadrilla, the company conducting shale gas drilling, has suspended operations after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months, occurred near Poulton-le-Fylde.

3. Shale gas drilling, or "fracking," involves fracturing underground shale rocks to release gas, using either hydraulic pressure or small explosions.

5. Fracking has been controversial in the US due to environmental concerns, including the potential for gas to leak into drinking water, possibly causing it to ignite.

7. The BGS is monitoring seismic activity related to fracking as a precautionary measure.
8. Since fracking began in Lancashire in March, there have been two minor earthquakes, including the most recent one.

A 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills and another woman in Stranraer were scammed by individuals pretending to be from BT technical support. Police Constable Siobhan Pellett warned about the alarming ease with which scammers can access victims' computers and emphasized the significant amounts of money being stolen. A Porthcawl RNLI crew, accompanied by a medic and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter, responded to an incident at Sker Beach, adjacent to Kenfig Nature Reserve, at 12:50 GMT on a Sunday. A UN conference in Geneva decided to allocate a portion of the radio spectrum for a global flight tracking system, aiming to enhance the existing system that depends on ground-based radars. The decision, made by representatives from over 160 countries at the World Radiocommunication Conference (WRC) organized by the UN's International Telecommunication Union (ITU), will allow satellites to receive automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions from aircraft, enabling real-time tracking of planes worldwide. This move was prompted by the disappearance of flight MH370 in March 2014, which highlighted the deficiencies in global air navigation systems, particularly the lack of coverage in about 70% of the world's airspace. Following MH370's disappearance, Malaysia's communication minister called for ITU's assistance in developing methods for real-time flight data transmission. The Malaysia Airlines flight, which vanished with 239 people on board while en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing, is believed to have crashed into the southern Indian Ocean. Debris from the plane, including part of a wing, was found on Reunion Island months later. The ITU Secretary-General, Houlin Zhao, praised the swift response to improve flight tracking. Additionally, the UN's International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has mandated the adoption of new tracking guidelines by November 2016, which will require aircraft to report their position at least every 15 minutes, with more frequent updates in emergencies.

18-year-old Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at the age of five, was found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. It was previously suspected that Bobby Hernandez might have been involved in his son's disappearance, with records indicating he had taken Julian to pre-school in 2002 but then fled with him.
