A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police are conducting a joint investigation with the Health and Safety Executive into the incident. Fruehauf is reportedly cooperating fully with the authorities in this investigation.

1. Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the dispute over seafarers' pay on freight vessels serving the Northern Isles.
2. The RMT union had raised concerns that some workers on the freight boats were paid less than £4 an hour.
3. The new charter will bring contracted out services back under the operation of Serco Northlink from next month.
4. The freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay are currently operated by Seatruck, which has been contracted by Serco Northlink.
5. Seatruck had argued that the national minimum wage did not apply to their crew, many of whom are non-UK residents.
6. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, but Seatruck did not agree to this.
7. The new charter arrangement, which is subject to finalizing financial and regulatory details, will ensure all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage.
8. The change is set to take effect early next month.
9. Serco Northlink holds a six-year, £243 million contract for the Northern Isles service, which includes three ferries and two cargo boats, and is heavily subsidized by the Scottish government.

64-year-old Ken Dickie died in the hospital on May 14, six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted to intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, with whom Mr. Dickie had been in a relationship for several years and was experiencing a rough patch. On May 7, Jamie Mitchell, who lived in Apple Close, visited his mother at the holiday park and became heavily intoxicated at the park's bar with her and Mr. Dickie. A confrontation between Jamie Mitchell and Mr. Dickie occurred outside, leading to a physical altercation that was broken up by bystanders. Jamie Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault related to this fight. Additionally, Jamie and Samantha Mitchell, both residing at Apple Close, admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially lying to the police about the incident, claiming Mr. Dickie had pushed Samantha and she had merely pushed him back in response. Jamie Mitchell later confessed to the police that he had attempted to separate the couple, resulting in what he described as a "tragic accident." The mother and son are due to be sentenced on February 6.

Rod Temperton, a renowned songwriter, passed away in London at the age of 66 following a short battle with cancer. He was known for writing hits such as "Off The Wall," "Baby Be Mine," and "Boogie Nights." Temperton's work with Michael Jackson on the albums "Off The Wall" and "Thriller," including the iconic title track, contributed significantly to Jackson's success and helped "Thriller" become the best-selling album in the US. He also collaborated with other prominent artists like Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, and The Brothers Johnson.

Temperton, who was nicknamed The Invisible Man for his low-key public profile, credited his father's influence for his songwriting talent, having grown up listening to Radio Luxembourg. He began his career in the 1970s with the disco group Heatwave, writing several hits for them before catching the attention of producer Quincy Jones. His songwriting achievements were recognized with a Grammy Award and two Oscar nominations.

Tributes poured in from the music industry, including from Chic guitarist Nile Rodgers, Michael Jackson's sister LaToya, producer and DJ Mark Ronson, and vocalist Chaka Khan, among others. Warner/Chappell's Jon Platt released a statement expressing the family's request for privacy during this difficult time. Temperton's approach to songwriting was to write something he loved first, aiming for that special feeling that signified a hit. His legacy includes a catalog of songs that have left a lasting impact on the music industry.

A team of researchers, including Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University, have discovered ancient earthworks in Acre state in the western Brazilian Amazon. These earthworks, which could be around 2,000 years old, consist of more than 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" that were hidden by bamboo-dominated rainforest until recent deforestation revealed them. The team, which also includes experts from the universities of Exeter and Reading, and Brazil's São Paulo and Belém, has been studying these enclosures.

The purpose of these geoglyphs remains largely unknown. They do not appear to have been permanent settlements or defensive structures, as few artifacts have been found and their layout is not indicative of such uses. Instead, it is speculated that they were used intermittently, possibly for rituals, similar to Maya pyramids or Stonehenge. Dr Loader's analysis of soil samples from the sites suggests that the geoglyphs were built in areas with taller vegetation, unlike the visible Maya pyramids, which raises questions about their visibility and purpose.

The research challenges the previous belief that the Amazonian forests were untouched by humans before the arrival of Europeans in the 16th century. Evidence indicates that over 6,000 years, humans introduced a variety of plant species, suggesting that the region was subject to ancient "agroforestry" practices. Rather than clearing large areas of forest, people seem to have focused on cultivating economically valuable trees, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of forest products. The team suggests that the biodiversity in some of Acre's remaining forests may be a legacy of these ancient practices.

21-year-old Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, defeated Sam Querrey, the world number 29, with a score of 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of a tournament. Kyrgios' victory comes shortly after winning the Japan Open, which has helped him approach a top 10 ranking. Despite his usual expressive nature on the court, Kyrgios appeared subdued during the match, attributing this to fatigue from his recent tournament win and the travel demands of competing at the Qi Zhong Stadium, which is located an hour away from Shanghai city center. He mentioned having poor sleep and arriving late the previous day, as well as an unpleasant commute to the courts. Kyrgios' comment about being tired contrasts with his behavior at the same tournament the previous year, where he was fined for calling the event a "circus" due to a foul-mouthed outburst.

1. The human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccine, which is known to protect against cervical cancer, is also believed to prevent head and neck cancers.
2. HPV is a sexually transmitted infection, and in Wales, girls aged 12 and 13 are vaccinated against it to protect them from cervical cancer.
3. The Welsh government is currently waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation regarding the potential expansion of the HPV vaccination program.
4. A coalition of charities and organizations, including Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team, is urging the Welsh government to extend the HPV vaccination to include boys.
5. They argue that the incidence of head and neck cancers is rising, with a notable impact on younger people, including men who are not smokers.
6. Dr. Mererid Evans highlights that the average age of those affected by head and neck cancers is 55, and three-quarters of the cases are in men.
7. Jon Antoniazzi from Tenovus Cancer Care emphasizes that HPV is responsible for 5% of the global cancer burden and advocates for the Welsh government to take a progressive step by vaccinating boys against HPV.
8. Since 2008, an HPV vaccination program has been in place in Welsh schools, with an 85% vaccination rate among girls in Wales.
9. The Welsh government has stated that it will consider the implications of any proposed changes to the HPV vaccination program once it receives recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation.

15-year-old Jak Trueman, who suffered from gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, a rare form of blood cancer, passed away and the news was shared by his mother, Allison, on his Facebook page. Jak had been chronicling his life and treatment on social media through a Facebook page called Jak's Journey, with the help of his mother, sister Aimie, and girlfriend Hannah Boyd. His positive attitude throughout his battle with cancer had touched many lives, and his page garnered over 28,000 Likes.

Despite his illness, Jak briefly attended his school prom and was honored with the presence of former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. He also received his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity at the event. Jak's journey included stays at hospitals in Edinburgh and Glasgow, visits from sports players and the cast of the musical Wicked, and personal moments shared online.

In January, Jak and his family were informed that his cancer had spread and that no further treatment would be pursued. Following this news, they encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. Jak enjoyed several special experiences after learning of his condition, including visiting the Kelpies, having a romantic meal with his girlfriend, and attending a party in his honor with Rangers FC players. A charity football match is scheduled to raise more funds for charity at the Energy Assets Arena, home of Livingston FC.

The passage describes a football match between Egypt and Uganda in which Egypt secured a late victory with a goal by Abdallah El Said in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. The match was otherwise uneventful, with few chances for either team and a resolute defensive performance from Uganda. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside by Joseph Ochaya earlier in the game. Egypt's win means they will face Ghana for the top spot in Group D, while Uganda is eliminated from the tournament after their first appearance since 1978. Ghana has already secured their place in the quarter-finals with a win over Mali. Egypt's goalkeeper Essam El Hadary and Uganda's keeper Denis Onyango both made notable contributions, with Onyango making an impressive header clearance and El Hadary punching away several set-pieces. The match ended with Egypt victorious by a score of 1-0.

1. Lancashire County Council has designated land from the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station. The sports college has closed, and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus is currently not in use.
2. The selection of this site was informed by a study conducted by Network Rail, which also considered a location near the Concourse shopping centre.
3. Skelmersdale's original railway station ceased passenger services in 1956.
4. The council, in collaboration with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, has proposed a service that would provide Skelmersdale with two direct trains to Liverpool every hour.
5. County Councillor John Fillis highlighted the project as an "exciting step forward," noting the preferred site's potential for future expansion, its good highway access, and its connectivity to the town and surrounding areas.
6. The council will begin the process of acquiring the necessary land for the project.
7. Skelmersdale, which was designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the northwest of England without a railway station.

A warehouse near Ashbourne was searched, leading to the discovery of plants in an "elaborate grow house." The discovery was made on a Saturday morning. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the location by police.

A 28-year-old woman was found with severe injuries on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was airlifted to a specialist clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from Bad Muender, turned himself in to the authorities following the incident. Both individuals are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive behind the attack is still under investigation, and the police have secured the area and appealed for witnesses to assist in the case.

The study conducted by Cass Business School, the University of Warwick, and the University of Wisconsin, involving 4,600 workers, found that women are equally likely to request a pay raise as men but are 25% less likely to receive one when they do ask. This finding contradicts the "reticent female" theory, which suggests that women are less inclined to ask for more money. The study specifically compared full-time males to full-time females and part-time males to part-time females to eliminate wage disparities based on working hours. It also considered factors such as employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications. The data used for the analysis came from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, which uniquely records whether employees requested a pay increase and their reasons for doing so or not. The findings suggest that the discrepancy in pay raise success rates between men and women may be due to discrimination rather than women's reluctance to ask. The study also noted that younger women under 40 are negotiating pay and conditions as successfully as their male counterparts, indicating a potential shift in negotiation behavior in the younger workforce.

1. Oxford City Council has been using funds primarily for ground investigations to find new burial sites, but no suitable locations have been identified.
2. The existing cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are expected to reach capacity by 2018 and 2021, respectively.
3. Despite the challenges, the council remains committed to finding new burial sites and is continuing to explore options.
4. Linda Smith, a board member, acknowledged the long-standing effort to locate a new burial site and highlighted the lack of suitable land within Oxford for this purpose.
5. All council-owned potential sites have been ruled out due to various issues such as size, ground conditions, high water tables, or restrictive covenants.
6. Once the current cemeteries are full, the council will only be able to accommodate burials in existing family plots, reserved plots, and the interment of ashes.
7. The last time Oxford saw an increase in burial space was in 1932.

1. The Hebridean Celtic Festival is introducing an app that allows visitors to access online content such as videos and band interviews by scanning items like signs and posters with their phones or tablets.
2. The festival is happening in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19 to 22.
3. Performers at the festival include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean.
4. HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan explained that the augmented reality feature is intended to enhance the festival experience for attendees and also enable people worldwide to engage with the festival and experience its atmosphere remotely.
5. The app will provide up-to-date messages, allowing users to access information, interviews, and purchase tickets both before and during the event. This feature aims to give a sense of the festival's unique environment to people regardless of their location.

10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse Many Clouds won the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day but collapsed and died shortly after the race. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) confirmed the cause of death as a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. Despite having shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, which caused overheating and unsteadiness, Many Clouds had no significant underlying health issues and had not displayed these symptoms on the day of the race. The BHA's acting chief veterinary officer, Tony Welsh, noted that such severe haemorrhages are rare and can occur in healthy horses across various equestrian sports. The BHA is committed to understanding the cause of such incidents and finding ways to prevent them. Many Clouds, owned by Trevor Hemmings and trained by Oliver Sherwood, was known for previous victories, including the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Despite his history of overheating, which was closely monitored, his death was attributed to the unexpected haemorrhage.

1. A 34-year-old individual named Davina Ayrton, who was previously known as David Ayrton, was found guilty of rape.
2. The offense took place in a Portsmouth garage in the autumn of 2004, when Ayrton was 15 years old.
3. The victim, also 15 at the time, testified that Ayrton raped her while two others were asleep nearby.
4. Ayrton denied the charge but was convicted and is due to be sentenced on 4 March.
5. Judge Ian Pearson remanded Ayrton into custody, expressing concern that she might pose a risk to herself or fail to attend her sentencing if released on bail.
6. Ayrton will likely be held at a male prison in Winchester, which the judge noted as an issue for the prison service, given her gender identity.
7. The court heard that Ayrton has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer, leading to protocols being put in place for her detention.
8. During the trial, Ayrton discussed her sexuality and stated that she had not undergone any physical changes, enhancements, or taken any medication.
9. Ayrton changed her name in 2012.
10. The victim reported the attack to a care home worker in 2014, which led to the case being brought to trial.

1. The Serbian tennis pair, which included world number one Novak Djokovic, lost to Brazil's Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in the Olympics in Rio with a score of 6-4 6-4.
2. This defeat followed Djokovic's singles loss to Juan Martin del Potro of Argentina the previous day.
3. Djokovic, aged 29, had previously experienced a surprise defeat in the third round at Wimbledon in July to American Sam Querrey.

1. The event is scheduled for Saturday in Carrbridge, located in the Cairngorms.
2. Over 20 competitors from various countries including Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US are expected to participate.

4. Last year's champion, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will compete again with the aim of defending his title and keeping the Claymore Trophy.

Rhys Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player, has been out of action since sustaining a foot injury during a World Cup warm-up match with Italy in September. He is nearing a return to the sport and is optimistic about being fit in time for the Six Nations tournament in February. Webb is currently undergoing a pre-season-like training regimen and reports that his recovery is progressing well. Although initially targeted to return at the beginning of February, he has requested and received confirmation from physiotherapists that he could potentially return a couple of weeks earlier than planned. Wales' Six Nations campaign kicks off against Ireland in Dublin on February 7. Webb, who has earned 16 caps for Wales, has decided to renew his national dual contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, rejecting offers from other teams. He expressed his commitment to his home region, the Ospreys, where he started his career in 2007, and his desire to continue playing for his country, stating that he is pleased to have finalized the contract renewal.

The passage describes an incident involving an attempt to smuggle MDMA (ecstasy) from Canada into the United States. The incident began when US border agents encountered two men, Jeffrey Laviolette and Nathan Hall, carrying backpacks near Sumas, Washington. One man fired at the agents and fled, while Laviolette was immediately apprehended. A manhunt ensued, and Hall, a Canadian citizen, was later arrested by the Abbotsford Police Department in British Columbia.

The backpacks carried by the men contained a total of 58 pounds (26 kilograms) of ecstasy. A California driver's license with Hall's photo but a different name was also found. Additionally, Kali Henifin and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were arrested for their involvement in the smuggling operation. Henifin and Lambert were allegedly planning to transport the drug couriers and were monitoring police radio. Lambert reportedly expected to be paid $11,000 for driving the drugs to San Francisco.

The three individuals arrested in the US face charges of conspiracy, as well as drug possession and distribution. The area where the incident occurred is known for smuggling activities, and such prosecutions are common in the region, according to a spokeswoman for the US attorney for the Western District of Washington.

1. The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant increase in the number of children counselled for online abuse, from about 2,400 in 2011-12 to more than 4,500 in the past year.
2. The actual number of children suffering from online abuse is believed to be much higher than the reported figures.
3. Children as young as seven have reported being tormented, abused, and scared to attend school due to online bullying.
4. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, emphasized the severe impact of bullying, which now extends beyond school grounds into cyber-bullying that can persecute children continuously.
5. Dame Esther Rantzen called for adult intervention, including that of parents and teachers, to protect children from bullying, stating that it typically does not stop on its own and tends to worsen if left unaddressed.
6. The report's release coincides with the start of Anti-Bullying Week, organized by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which is collaborating with various stakeholders to address the issue.
7. A young person shared their experience of being cyber-bullied, including being told to kill themselves, and expressed the difficulty in dealing with the situation, despite parental advice to stand up for themselves or stop playing online games.

1. The passage describes the aftermath of the US abstaining from a UN Security Council vote on a resolution demanding an end to Israeli settlement construction, which was seen as a significant shift in US policy and infuriated Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
2. Netanyahu accused the Obama administration of helping draft the resolution and pushing for its passage, which the US State Department denied.
3. The resolution, which passed on December 23, 2016, declared that Israeli settlements in the West Bank and East Jerusalem have no legal validity, are in violation of international law, and are obstacles to peace and the two-state solution.
4. Israel, which disputes the illegality of the settlements, rejected the resolution and took diplomatic actions in response, such as summoning ambassadors, recalling its own ambassadors from New Zealand and Senegal, cutting aid to Senegal, and canceling a visit by the Ukrainian prime minister.
5. A planned vote on authorizing new housing units in the settlements was postponed at the request of Netanyahu's office to avoid further tension with the US ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
6. Kerry's speech was expected to address the conflict and respond to Israeli criticisms of the Obama administration.
7. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the resolution, hoping it would lead to a mechanism and timetable to end the Israeli occupation at an upcoming peace conference in France.

The passage provides an overview of events and reflections surrounding Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday. Key points include:

1. The Queen was praised by Prince William in a BBC interview as a "guiding example" of an ideal monarch, highlighting her duty, service, tolerance, and commitment.
2. A set of stamps featuring four generations of the Royal Family (Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George) was released to commemorate the Queen's birthday.
3. The Queen, accompanied by the Duke of Edinburgh, visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office to celebrate the 500th anniversary of the postal service and later opened a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens, where schoolchildren sang Happy Birthday.
4. Political leaders, including Prime Minister David Cameron, expressed their admiration for the Queen and her service to the nation.
5. Prince William addressed criticism of being "work-shy," stating his commitment to duty and the importance of finding his own way in his royal role, with the support of his family.
6. The Queen and Prince Philip will participate in a walk in Windsor and light a beacon to initiate a series of beacons across the UK and the world in honor of her birthday.
7. US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama are scheduled to have lunch with the Queen at Windsor Castle.
8. The Queen celebrates two birthdays each year: her actual birthday on April 21st and her official birthday on a Saturday in June.
9. The republican group Republic criticized the BBC's extensive coverage of the Queen's birthday, arguing that it was not proportionate or balanced reporting.

This summary captures the essence of the passage, focusing on the tributes, events, and reactions surrounding the Queen's 90th birthday, as well as the broader discussion about the role of the monarchy and its media coverage.

The passage describes a football match between League Two side Cheltenham Town and Premier League side West Ham United in the EFL Cup. West Ham took control of the game before half-time with two quick goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew. Sakho scored his first goal since November from Sam Byram's pass, and Ayew followed up with a goal into the same corner. Cheltenham had chances with Harry Pell's volley and Jordon Forster's header, but failed to convert. West Ham, who made seven changes after recent Premier League losses, could have increased their lead through James Collins and Sam Byram. Cheltenham's best opportunity came when Dan Holman nearly connected with Pell's volley across the goal. The match was a repeat of a fixture from four years prior, which West Ham also won 2-1 at Upton Park. Despite a respectable performance from Cheltenham, they did not test West Ham's goalkeeper Adrian sufficiently and West Ham had chances to win by a larger margin, with Kyle Storer clearing a header off the line and Jonathan Flatt saving a potential goal from Sakho. The 2-0 victory for West Ham ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup ahead of the third-round draw.

36-year-old hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion when Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old man from Leipzig, failed to see McNicholl's motorcycle and turned his VW Transporter into its path. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court. He was fined £1,000, banned from driving in the UK for two years, but avoided jail time as McNicholl's family did not see value in imprisoning Werner, considering it a momentary lapse. Werner, who was staying near Bala with his family, expressed remorse and could not explain the cause of the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, is facing a potential life sentence for his activities as a jihadist in Syria. He left the UK in January of the previous year and became known as Abu Daigham al-Britani, actively posting videos and images of his experiences on the battlefield. Khawaja was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State, which produced slick propaganda to recruit young British Muslims. Despite the group's portrayal of jihad as glamorous and noble, their online content also included disturbing images of violence, including one of Khawaja holding a bag with a severed head.

Upon his return to the UK, Khawaja attempted to conceal his entry and even faked his own death online. His cousin, Tahir Bhatti, assisted him in his return, for which Bhatti has admitted to assisting an offender. The British security service MI5 was monitoring Khawaja, and he was arrested upon arrival at Dover. Commander Richard Walton of the Metropolitan Police's counter-terrorism command described Khawaja as a dangerous individual who had chosen the path of terrorism and had been held in a special unit at Belmarsh prison. Khawaja has pleaded guilty to four offences, while the charge of soliciting to murder will remain on file.

22-year-old Kayden Jackson, who scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, has been signed by Barnsley as their third signing for the upcoming season. Wrexham finished eighth in the table. Barnsley is set to play in the League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday. Barnsley's caretaker boss, Paul Heckingbottom, praised Jackson's pace and ability to challenge defenders, stating that he will integrate well with the team's playing style. Jackson declined a contract renewal offer from Wrexham to join Barnsley. For more information on football transfers, a dedicated page is available.

- The public has been advised to keep children and dogs away from the bottles and not to attempt to recover them.

1. Lord Oates of the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) criticized Labour for being willing to "concede everything" regarding Brexit negotiations.
2. Labour's leader in the Lords, Baroness Smith, accused the Lib Dems of giving people "false hope."
3. The two parties had previously cooperated to defeat the government on issues related to EU citizens' rights and the need for parliamentary approval of a Brexit deal.
4. Cooperation ceased when the House of Commons rejected these amendments, with the Lib Dems insisting on them while Labour was willing to defer to the Commons' decision.
5. A Labour source in the Lords described the Lib Dems' actions as "fairly obvious grandstanding" for campaign material, criticizing them for raising false hope among those worried about their future in Britain.
6. Lib Dem Europe spokesperson Baroness Ludford criticized Labour for "waving through the government's plans" and aligning with the Conservatives to push for a hard Brexit.
7. Despite tensions on Brexit, the two parties have a history of alliances, having jointly defeated the government on various issues, including higher education and housing.
8. Baroness Ludford expressed openness to future cooperation on issues of shared concern.
9. However, a Labour source predicted lingering tensions and doubted the likelihood of a "progressive consensus summer drinks" gathering to mend relations.
10. Despite the tensions, both parties were expected to maintain a professional relationship, with the Lib Dems committed to working with peers across the House and Labour acknowledging the need for a business-like approach.

1. Defence is a low priority in the current election, ranking outside the top electorate concerns such as the economy, NHS, and immigration. This is partly due to public combat fatigue from UK military interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Libya.
2. Both the Labour and Conservative parties have brief mentions of their defence policies on page 77 of their manifestos, lacking detail and avoiding tough decisions.
3. Despite a perceived increase in global instability and threats, European nations, including the UK, have cut their military forces. The UK Army is reducing to 82,000, the Navy has 19 warships, and the RAF will soon have seven fast jet squadrons, indicating capability gaps.
4. The UK has fallen from fourth to sixth in global defence spending, and current projections suggest it may fall below the NATO threshold of spending 2% of GDP on defence, potentially impacting its credibility with allies like the US.
5. None of the major parties plan to ring-fence defence spending, meaning further cuts are likely, with the MoD's £34bn budget at risk. The Conservatives have made some defence commitments that may limit their ability to make significant savings.
6. The future of the UK's nuclear deterrent, Trident, is uncertain, with the Conservatives and UKIP supporting a like-for-like replacement, Labour considering a reduced submarine fleet, the Liberal Democrats advocating for a part-time deterrent, and the SNP and Greens wanting to scrap it entirely.
7. The UK will have two new aircraft carriers by the end of the decade, but there are concerns about crewing and equipping them adequately, highlighting the risk of a "hollow force" with insufficient personnel and resources.
8. The next Strategic Defence Review will need to address these issues, including the nuclear programme's impact on conventional forces, and how to maintain the UK's military influence on the world stage.

1. Barcelona stated they had not committed any offence regarding the transfer of Neymar and made a tax declaration to address potential interpretations of the contracts involved in his signing.
2. The total cost of Neymar's transfer, including the initial fee, signing-on fee, wages, agents fees, and the latest tax payment, amounts to £106.8m.
3. Neymar's parents received £34m of the £48.6m transfer fee from Santos to Barcelona.
4. Former Barcelona president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriation of funds related to the transfer, though he denies any wrongdoing.
5. Barcelona initially reported the transfer fee as 57m euros, but it was alleged that the actual cost, including other contracts, was higher.
6. A Spanish judge found enough evidence to continue investigating the transfer, leading to Barcelona's additional tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros.
7. Despite the payment, it is not confirmed whether the case against Barcelona will be dropped.
8. On the pitch, Neymar has performed well, scoring 7 goals in 18 league appearances and 3 in 7 Champions League matches for Barcelona during the season in question.

27-year-old Michael Luciw from Nottingham was killed in a car accident when the van he was a passenger in was struck by a Mazda Premacy driven by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died in the collision. Newman was driving the wrong way on the motorway. Luciw's family has called for mandatory regular driving tests for retired individuals, suggesting that aging affects driving abilities. Luciw, a father and delivery driver, was on a long-distance trip when the accident occurred on October 12 near Kegworth, Leicestershire. His colleague, Andy Harrington, who was driving the van, reported that he barely had time to react to Newman's vehicle traveling north in the southbound lane. Harrington, who was seriously injured in the crash, also supports the idea of medical examinations for elderly drivers.

In the UK, drivers over 70 must renew their licenses every three years by completing a self-assessment form, which does not require a medical or driving test. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) has no plans to change licensing rules based on age, stating that evidence does not show older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents. They emphasize that drivers over 70 must declare any medical conditions that could impact their driving.

Age UK, a charity supporting older people, emphasizes the importance of driving for the independence it provides to the elderly, advocating for support to help them drive safely for as long as possible.

The topic will be further explored in the BBC One East Midlands program "Inside Out" on January 25 and will be available on iPlayer for 30 days after the initial broadcast.

1. Women have raised concerns about the safety of mesh implants used for treating incontinence due to severe side effects.
2. Two members of the original review group resigned, protesting that the report was too lenient.
3. An independent expert, Professor Alison Britton from Glasgow Caledonian University, will review the final report.
4. Health Secretary Shona Robison informed the public petitions committee that Professor Britton would assess the review process and suggest improvements for the future.
5. The report recommended against routinely offering the procedures for pelvic organ prolapse and suggested a range of treatment options with comprehensive information for patients to make informed choices.
6. It also recommended mandatory reporting of adverse events related to the implants.
7. Despite calls for a ban, Robison confirmed the implementation of the report's recommendations, noting that the Scottish government lacks the authority to ban the procedures, which rests with the UK's Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency.
8. Tracey Gillies, chairwoman of the independent review, apologized for not achieving unanimous agreement among panel members for the final report.
9. Gillies, who took over the review in its final stages, faced criticism from affected women during her testimony.
10. Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, both of whom experienced complications from mesh surgery, resigned from the review group, expressing dismay and disgust with the report, alleging that content had been omitted.
11. A consultant also resigned from the expert group due to concerns about the final draft of the report.
12. Over the past two decades, more than 20,000 women in Scotland have received mesh or tape implants, with some experiencing severe complications, leading to over 400 women taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

23-year-old Laura Muir broke the 25-year-old 5000m indoor British record previously held by Liz McColgan, finishing with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan expressed excitement about the record being broken and acknowledged Muir's potential to win world medals. Despite initial concerns raised by McColgan regarding the legitimacy of the race as a "genuine" record-breaking attempt, since Muir was the only competitor finishing the 5000m distance, British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time was expected to be officially recognized. McColgan also noted that Muir, who is a 3.55 minute 1500m runner, has the potential to run even faster, possibly around 14.30 for the 5000m. McColgan drew parallels between Muir's race and her own record-breaking run 25 years ago, where she also lapped other runners, including a young Paula Radcliffe. She praised Muir as world-class and emphasized the importance of race tactics for Muir to win medals at the world level. Muir's recent achievements also include breaking her own British 1500m record and reaching the 1500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

Michael Jung of Germany won a gold medal in equestrian at the Rio Olympics, riding Sam, who was a last-minute substitute for Fischertakinou due to an infection. French rider Astier Nicolas secured the silver medal, and American Phillip Dutton took home the bronze. British rider William Fox-Pitt, who had made a remarkable recovery from a serious fall just 10 months prior, finished in 12th place. Despite a flawless show-jumping performance on the final day, Fox-Pitt's chances for a medal were dashed by a subpar cross-country phase that resulted in several time penalties, dropping him from the lead after the dressage phase to 21st place. Another notable finish was by Ireland's Jonty Evans, who placed ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift. The passage also invites readers to engage with equestrian sports by meeting and riding Henry, a mechanical horse, at official Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics, and offers a guide on getting into equestrian sports. Additionally, it promotes subscribing to the BBC Sport newsletter for updates on sports news, features, and videos.

30-year-old British tennis player Andy Murray advanced to the last 16 of the tournament after defeating 29th seed Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5. The match lasted two hours and 39 minutes, with Murray winning the final point at 20:57 BST. Despite Fognini having five set points to push the match to a fifth set, Murray secured victory by winning five consecutive games. Murray will face Benoit Paire of France in the fourth round on Monday. Earlier, fellow Briton Johanna Konta also progressed to the second week of the tournament for the first time.

Murray acknowledged the match's tension and variable quality, expressing relief at winning before darkness necessitated a delay to close the roof. Fognini displayed both skill and volatility, coming close to extending the match but ultimately succumbing to Murray's resilience. The fourth set was particularly dramatic, with Fognini receiving a penalty for an obscene gesture and Murray complaining about the Italian's slow play. Murray saved set points in three consecutive games to level the set at 5-5 before clinching the match. Murray noted he didn't feel as agile as in previous matches but was content to have navigated the first week of the tournament, optimistic about his chances moving forward.

1. Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven due to a sudden death on 6 October 2014 at 06:00 BST.
2. Police found patrons still at the bar when they arrived, with evidence of alcohol being served until 04:49 BST.
3. The court ordered Joe's Bar to close for three months.
4. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both of Kevin Lynch Park, Dungiven, were charged with allowing the consumption of alcohol outside of licensing hours.
5. The defense acknowledged that the licensing laws were not followed and that the premises were not properly managed, operating into the morning hours.
6. The judge criticized Ms. O'Neill's "appalling record" and noted the severity of the case, but lacked the power to impose a custodial sentence.
7. Ms. O'Neill was fined £3,000 and Mr. Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party (UUP), emphasized the importance of partnership over domination at the launch of his party's manifesto. The UUP aims to make the election a judgment on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal. However, Nesbitt's own comments have become a focal point, particularly after his colleague Danny Kennedy distanced himself from them. Nesbitt responded positively to Kennedy's action, seeing it as a sign of active listening.

During the event, Nesbitt faced questions about his remarks and whether he had any regrets. He maintained his stance, advocating for voters to support UUP candidates and then choose any candidate they believe will act in the best interest of their community and country. He expressed a preference for forming a government with the SDLP over Sinn Féin and reported positive feedback while canvassing in unionist areas.

The UUP manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', outlines several key policies, including reducing waiting lists, increasing the number of PSNI officers to 7,500, prioritizing the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, and ensuring no group is disadvantaged by Brexit. It also includes a section on 'Cleaning Up Stormont'.

Nesbitt framed the election as a referendum on the "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption" in the government. Despite the controversy surrounding his remarks about transferring votes to the SDLP, he remains hopeful that his message will resonate with the public, especially in light of the ongoing Renewable Heat Incentive scandal and the DUP and Sinn Féin's decade-long rule.

23-year-old Laura Muir from Kinross broke the Scottish record in the 1500m race with a time of 4:19.12, finishing second to Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This performance surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and placed Muir second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir expressed her pleasure at achieving the Scottish record, which is significant to her. She now holds both the Scottish 1500m and mile records and is looking forward to the rest of the season, starting with her recent 800m victory in France. Muir, who balances her athletic career with her veterinary studies, is aiming to secure a spot for the Olympics at the British trials in Birmingham later in June. Her next competition is a 1500m race in Stockholm, and she is confident following a successful training period. Yvonne Murray's husband, Tom Mooney, congratulated Muir on her achievement.

1. The passage indicates that there are 26 beaches in Scotland that have been recognized for their "most excellent" water quality.
2. The mention of "your pictures" suggests that the information provided may include visual documentation or user-generated content of these beaches.
3. The focus is on the high standard of water quality at these Scottish beaches, which is a key factor in their ranking and recognition.

The passage describes the findings and conclusions presented by Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC regarding the murder of Alexander Litvinenko. Horwell asserts that the suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, had no personal motive to kill Litvinenko and suggests that the Russian state likely sponsored the plot to assassinate him. Litvinenko, a former Russian agent who defected to the UK, was fatally poisoned with polonium-210 in London in 2006. Horwell emphasizes that the use of polonium points to Russian state involvement, though he clarifies that there is no evidence directly implicating Russian President Vladimir Putin in the murder.

Litvinenko's defection and his public criticism of Putin and the FSB could have been perceived as treachery, providing the Russian state with motives for his assassination. Horwell also notes that Litvinenko had been poisoned twice before his death, and the suspects left a trail of polonium evidence behind. The long-term risks to the public from polonium exposure remain unknown.

Despite the Met Police's desire to see Kovtun and Lugovoi stand trial for murder, extradition attempts have been unsuccessful, and the suspects remain in Russia. The inquiry has been adjourned until Friday, with Kovtun, a former Soviet army officer, being criticized for not providing evidence to the hearing.

26-year-old Steve Smith has been appointed as the ongoing captain of the Australian cricket team for both the one-day and Twenty20 formats, taking over from the injured Aaron Finch for the latter. David Warner, 28, will serve as Smith's vice-captain. Smith's leadership role was solidified after Michael Clarke's retirement following the Ashes series loss to England. Smith had previously captained the team in three Tests against India. He has played 32 Tests and has an impressive average of 54.66. Rod Marsh, the national selector, praised Smith as a talented young leader and expressed confidence in his ability to fill Clarke's role. Warner's appointment as vice-captain marks a significant milestone for him, given his past disciplinary issues, but Marsh noted his maturity and development as a senior player. Smith and Warner are set to lead Australia in the upcoming limited-overs matches after the final Ashes Test at the Oval.

1. Tim Farron, the leader of a liberal party, has been questioned about his views on homosexual sex as a sin. He did not provide a direct answer when asked three times, instead stating that "we are all sinners."
2. Despite the lack of a clear response on the sin issue, Farron has expressed strong support for LGBT-plus rights and has made defending equal marriage a priority, indicating it would be a top agenda item during his leadership.
3. He has also voiced his intention to extend marital rights to transgender individuals, highlighting the issue of the spousal veto which requires a spouse's consent for a marriage to continue after one partner changes gender.
4. Farron was challenged on his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill, which aimed to prevent discrimination against gay people by businesses. He explained that his party had concerns about the protection of individual liberties and tabled an amendment to the bill. When the amendment failed, he voted against the bill.
5. Farron has asserted his commitment to equality and LGBT-plus rights, emphasizing his belief in equal access under the law for all people regardless of their sexuality.

Sanofi, a French company, shut down its drug manufacturing facility in Fawdon in 2015, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare has plans to revive the plant for pharmaceutical production and is optimistic about filling many of the positions with former Sanofi employees. An Accord spokesman expressed confidence that the investment would have a highly positive impact on the local area. Newcastle City Council leader, Councillor Nick Forbes, welcomed the news, highlighting that it reinforces the region's reputation as a hub for the science and healthcare industry. He noted that Accord Healthcare, a significant player in the global pharmaceutical market, will bring highly skilled jobs and long-term investment, providing a boost to the local economy. Accord Healthcare is known for developing, manufacturing, and distributing over 130 pharmaceutical products to approximately 60 countries around the world.

1. Richard Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving the council on Friday at the end of his contract.
2. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are both departing through a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme.
3. Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, expressed that these departures reflect the council's struggle to retain senior staff and predicted more departures in the near future.
4. Council chief executive Angela Scott acknowledged the dedication and professionalism of the three departing individuals.

The English rider, referred to as Martin, experienced a crash during this year's Tourist Trophy (TT) race, and the Honda Fireblade bike he was riding has been troubled by mechanical issues. Initially, Martin announced his departure from road racing to MCN, but he later provided further details on Facebook. He clarified that while he has not given up on racing entirely, he has no intention of continuing to race on Hondas for the remainder of the year. Following his team-mate John McGuinness's crash during practice, Martin did not participate in the North West 200. Additionally, he will not be competing in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix. Martin expressed his dissatisfaction with the TT, stating it was a "bloody disaster," with the only enjoyable moments being walking his dog and racing the Mugen. He acknowledged that even before the TT, it was evident that they would face challenges. His role seemed to shift towards that of a test rider, a role he embraced. However, after further testing at Cadwell, Martin informed his team that the bike would not be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix. Consequently, the team decided to withdraw him from the event without directly informing him, a decision he accepted. Martin indicated that he has no unresolved issues in racing and expressed his interest in racing classic and unconventional motorcycles in the future.

1. The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory in the Nigerian governorship elections, winning 19 out of 28 available positions, marking the biggest loss for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999.
2. The PDP, which had previously lost the presidential election to APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, also lost governorships in key northern states such as Katsina and Kaduna, as well as in Adamawa, a state affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP retained control of Rivers State, the country's oil hub, and won eight governorships, primarily in the south-east.
3. The APC's victories have reduced the PDP's influence to mainly the south-east and Niger Delta regions, with the party's national spread significantly diminished. The APC did not win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose challenges for President-elect Buhari in managing potential disruptions to oil production by militant groups.
4. Elections were not violence-free, with the Independent National Electoral Commission (Inec) reporting 66 violent incidents, mostly in Rivers and other southern states. Despite this, the elections were considered more peaceful than previous years, suggesting progress in Nigeria's democratic processes.
5. The results in Taraba state are still outstanding, and the election in Imo state was declared inconclusive due to a high number of spoilt ballots. Elections were not held in seven states.
6. The APC's victory in Lagos state is particularly noteworthy as it is the first time since 1999 that the president's party will control both the presidency and Lagos, Nigeria's commercial capital.
7. The PDP is expected to undergo a period of self-reflection and rebuilding following the loss of power after 16 years, during which it faced corruption allegations and criticism for its handling of the Boko Haram insurgency. The party had also been weakened by the defection of governors and legislators to the APC prior to the elections.

1. Mighty, a US environmental lobby group, has accused agricultural commodities trader Olam and its major stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek, of contributing to the haze problem in Southeast Asia through unsustainable palm oil trading practices. Both Olam and Temasek reject these allegations.

2. The haze in Singapore and Malaysia is caused by slash-and-burn practices used by small-scale farmers and rogue palm oil traders in Indonesia, particularly in the regions of Riau, South Sumatra, and Kalimantan. Indonesia has been criticized for not adequately addressing these agricultural fires.

3. Olam, which is based in Singapore, purchases 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and accounts for less than 1% of the global palm oil market. Mighty's report suggests that Olam's trading practices may inadvertently support unsustainable palm oil production that contributes to the haze.

4. Olam has a strict sourcing policy that prohibits burning, deforestation, and peatland development. The company has recently released the names of its 14 suppliers and is in the process of vetting them to ensure compliance with its sustainability standards.

5. Temasek, as the majority shareholder in Olam, could be implicated in the annual haze if Olam is found to be sourcing from rogue palm oil producers. Temasek supports no-burn policies but maintains that it does not intervene in the business operations of its portfolio companies.

6. The palm oil industry is a significant global market but is also associated with environmental destruction, illegal labor practices, and conflicts with local communities. There is a debate between environmental groups and palm oil companies regarding the industry's responsibility and ability to monitor third-party suppliers.

7. In Gabon, Mighty accuses Olam of clearing rainforests for palm oil plantations, mirroring the practices that have caused extensive damage in Southeast Asia. Olam defends its actions in Gabon, stating that its partnerships with the government are responsible and transparent, and that only a small percentage of least valuable forested land is being converted for agriculture in a sustainable manner.

27 August 2016 Last updated at 12:34 BST A restaurant started offering puppy platters following the introduction of a new law that permits dogs to dine at restaurants, provided they are seated outdoors. A video clip showcases this canine-friendly dining option.

1. Fernando Forestieri, a forward, is uncertain for the next game due to a knee injury, having been limited to a substitute role in the past two matches.
2. Striker David Nugent of Derby County may be available for selection again after sitting out the recent match against Huddersfield due to a groin issue.
3. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield, who scored an equalizing goal as a substitute in the match against Huddersfield, is looking to be reinstated in the starting lineup.

1. Pakistan's telecoms regulator lifted a ban on YouTube after Google introduced a Pakistan-specific version of the site.
2. The ban was initially imposed in 2012 by the Supreme Court due to the uploading of the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims," which led to protests and deaths in Pakistan.
3. Google has established a process for the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) to request the blocking of offensive material directly through an online web process.
4. YouTube has stated that it will not automatically grant requests from governments to remove content and that such requests will be subject to a thorough review and recorded in its Transparency Report.
5. The lifting of the ban has been welcomed by many young Pakistanis, but some activists are calling for transparency regarding the agreement between Google and the Pakistani government.
6. The Pakistan Telecommunication Company Ltd announced the return of YouTube on its Facebook page, and the ministry of information technology has outlined the new process for content restriction.
7. Blasphemy is a serious crime in Pakistan, punishable by death, although such sentences have not been carried out.
8. Google recently launched local versions of YouTube for several countries, including Pakistan, Nepal, and Sri Lanka.

1. Domenico Scala, a Swiss-Italian national, is the head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee and did not step down from his position for the upcoming February 26th elections, despite sharing nationality with one of the five presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino.
2. In contrast, Scala and another committee member, Claudio Sulser, both Swiss, had excused themselves from the 2015 elections to avoid a potential conflict of interest since one of the candidates, Sepp Blatter, was also Swiss and the incumbent president.
3. Musa Bility, president of the Liberian Football Association (LFA), has threatened to take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday, citing a conflict of interest as per Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations.
4. Bility, who himself was denied candidacy in November after failing an eligibility check, has pledged his support to Prince Ali of Jordan, one of the five candidates vying to replace the long-standing president Sepp Blatter.
5. The other candidates in the race are Frenchman Jerome Champagne, Bahrain's Sheikh Salman, and South Africa's Tokyo Sexwale, with the election to be held in Zurich, Switzerland, and decided by Fifa's 209 members.
6. Andreas Bantel, a spokesman for Scala, has stated that there is no conflict of interest in the current election as there is no incumbent president, and the regulations do not mandate Scala's withdrawal based on shared nationality with a candidate.

29-year-old Daniel Timbers and 56-year-old Barry Joy were fatally injured at Harford Attachments on Spar Road while working in a paint-spraying area. The incident occurred shortly after 09:00 BST on a Monday, and their bodies were removed the following afternoon. A forensic search was conducted at the site, which is a manufacturer of digger buckets. Detective Chief Inspector Paul Durham reported that there had been a flashover explosion, likely due to a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition source, causing a fireball. The Health and Safety Executive is involved in the investigation, with inspectors and electrical safety experts collecting evidence.

Tunisia narrowly avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to the Confederation of African Football (Caf) for complaints they made during the 2015 tournament. The controversy arose from a disputed penalty decision in their quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea, which Tunisia felt was unjustifiable and possibly influenced by the crowd. Despite media reports, the Tunisian Football Federation clarified that they did not accuse Caf or the referee of corruption but did question the referee's appointment and capability.

Morocco, on the other hand, was allowed to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned their ban. Morocco had been punished for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola fears, seeking a postponement instead. Cas not only lifted the ban but also reduced the fine imposed on the Moroccan Football Association from $1m to $50,000.

Fouzi Lekjaa, the Moroccan FA chief, expressed optimism for the future of African and Moroccan football, downplaying the impact of the ban. Equatorial Guinea had stepped in as hosts for the 2015 finals with only 64 days to prepare.

The resolution of the disputes with Caf means that both Tunisia and Morocco are now focused on the 2017 Nations Cup qualifiers. Tunisia, aiming for their first Nations Cup win since 2004, will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will compete against Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F. If Tunisia qualifies for the finals in Gabon, it will mark their thirteenth consecutive appearance at the tournament, setting a new record.

1. A mass confrontation occurred in the 95th minute of a match between Chelsea and Manchester City at Etihad Stadium, which Chelsea won 3-1.
2. Manchester City players Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off during the incident.
3. Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face additional disciplinary action.
4. Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement in the altercation.
5. Aguero, aged 28, was banned for four matches due to his second violent conduct offense of the season, a high and late challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz.
6. Fernandinho was involved in a clash with Fabregas after Aguero's challenge and received a three-match ban.
7. Both Manchester City and Chelsea have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge related to the incident.

The passage discusses a pilot program in Cwm Cynon and Neath Port Talbot in Wales aimed at improving cancer diagnosis rates, which are among the worst in the developed world. The program focuses on patients who exhibit no clear symptoms or signs of cancer but are suspected to be at risk. This initiative follows a visit by local doctors to Denmark to observe their diagnostic systems, which have been credited with improving cancer diagnosis rates.

The concern in Wales is that patients without clear symptoms may wait too long for a diagnosis and may not fit neatly into specific treatment pathways. General practitioners (GPs) often refer these patients for multiple tests over several weeks. Consequently, there is a fear that too many patients start treatment when their cancer is too advanced to be effectively treated.

In Cwm Cynon, 40 GPs believe that referring patients to the diagnostic center at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital in Llantrisant within seven days could lead to a more efficient process. The plan is for around six patients per week to be seen and to undergo different tests on the same day. Currently, only 35% of patients with "borderline" symptoms receive a diagnosis in the Cwm Taf area, and doctors aim to reach more of the patient population without such clear symptoms.

A similar trial clinic is being set up at Neath Port Talbot Hospital as part of another pilot program by the Abertawe Bro Morgannwg University Health Board. These trials have been developed over the 12 months since specialists returned from Aarhus, Denmark, where diagnostic centers were established following concerns about the country's cancer diagnosis rates.

Dr. Gareth Davies, Director of the Wales Cancer Network, states that the program will not only reassure patients but also streamline the process. GPs who are unsure about a patient's condition but have concerns can quickly refer them to the clinic, ensuring prompt attention and hopefully a swift diagnosis.

GP Dr. Gareth Jordan from Aberdare suggests that the pilot program could make a significant difference in patients' lives by providing timely and coordinated specialist opinions, which is crucial for early diagnosis and effective treatment.

If the Cwm Cynon pilot program, set to begin within six months, is successful, other health boards in the region are expected to offer the same service subsequently.

England secured a victory over Pakistan by a significant margin of runs at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a day to spare. They declared their first innings at 589-8 and their second at 173-1, setting up their second-largest win against Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was awarded man of the match for his exceptional performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and remaining unbeaten on 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also contributed with the ball and in the field, taking four catches and claiming a wicket.

England's captain Alastair Cook praised Root's innings as one of the best he had seen, highlighting his responsibility and skill at the number three position. Root himself acknowledged his previous errors at Lord's and expressed satisfaction with his more controlled play in this match. Coach Trevor Bayliss commended Root for his hard work and dedication to improvement following the first Test.

Pakistan struggled throughout the match, batting for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second on a pitch that offered little to the bowlers. Their captain, Misbah-ul-Haq, admitted to the team's disappointment, citing a lack of confidence and poor shot selection as key factors in their defeat. Geoffrey Boycott noted that Pakistan's spirit was broken, and he predicted that England would continue to dominate the series.

Despite the comprehensive victory, Michael Vaughan cautioned that the series could still be very tight, while also praising England's performance. Pakistan will look to regroup in a two-day tour game against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston. Misbah remains hopeful that his team, known for their mental strength, will bounce back from this defeat.

1. Warren Gatland, the head coach of the British and Irish Lions, has included Rob Howley as an interim coach in his team for the tour in New Zealand.
2. Forwards coach Robin McBryde will serve as the head coach for Wales for the third time, having previously led tours in 2009 and 2013.
3. McBryde expressed his honor and excitement about leading the team again, emphasizing the added responsibility of representing the country abroad.
4. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is in the process of appointing assistant coaches to support McBryde for the summer tour.
5. WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips stated that discussions are underway with potential candidates for the summer tour, with the aim of finalizing the management team shortly.
6. Gareth Davies, the chairman of the WRU and a member of the Lions' selection panel, believes that the involvement of Welsh coaches in the Lions' tour will be beneficial for the development of Welsh rugby.
7. Davies highlighted the unique opportunity for Welsh coaches to grow in different environments and noted that past Lions experiences have been invigorating for coaches and players, expecting the tour in New Zealand to be a significant challenge that will inspire the team.

The passage describes a Premier League match between Hull City and Southampton, which ended with a 2-1 victory for Hull City, marking their first league win since 20 August and ending a six-game losing streak. Despite Charlie Austin's early penalty giving Southampton the lead, Hull City turned the game around in the second half with two quick goals from Robert Snodgrass and Michael Dawson. Snodgrass, who came on as a substitute for the injured Will Keane, scored the equalizer and then provided the assist for Dawson's header. Southampton had several chances to equalize, but Hull's goalkeeper David Marshall made a series of impressive saves. The match was also notable for Hull's resilience despite losing two strikers, Abel Hernandez and Will Keane, to injuries in the first half. Hull City's manager Mike Phelan expressed pride in his team's performance, while Southampton's manager Claude Puel acknowledged his team's lack of concentration and the difficulty of maintaining form after European matches. The win lifted the mood at the KCOM Stadium, although Hull remained in the bottom three of the league table. Following the international break, Hull City will face Sunderland, and Southampton will play against Liverpool.

1. A fatal crash occurred around 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa.
2. The collision involved a motorcyclist and a tractor.
3. The motorcyclist, a local resident, was killed. The tractor driver was uninjured.
4. Lincolnshire Police have not disclosed additional details about the motorcyclist.
5. The police are appealing for witnesses to the collision.
6. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle following the incident.

1. The President of Macedonia, Ivanov, cancelled an investigation into alleged abuse of power, which was revealed through covert recordings, to end the political turmoil before the early elections in June.
2. The decision to halt the investigation was met with criticism from both the opposition and the European Union (EU) officials, who viewed it as undermining the rule of law.
3. Macedonia has been experiencing political chaos since the release of the recordings in 2015, which seem to implicate government officials in various misdeeds, including election fraud and the concealment of a murder.
4. In a televised speech, President Ivanov defended his actions as necessary to protect national interests and stated his intention to resolve the ongoing political crisis.
5. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev criticized the President's move as illegal and called for public protests in Skopje, the capital.
6. The EU Enlargement Commissioner, Johannes Hahn, expressed that President Ivanov's actions were inconsistent with the principle of rule of law and could jeopardize Macedonia's prospects of joining the EU.
7. The political crisis began with the release of secret recordings by Zaev, which he claims show widespread government corruption, including wiretapping of thousands of individuals, misuse of funds, questionable legal actions against political adversaries, and attempts to cover up killings.
8. The Macedonian government has denied all allegations made by Zaev and has accused him of attempting to destabilize the country, an accusation he rejects.

1. Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will temporarily manage Swansea for the match against Bournemouth following the dismissal of Bob Bradley.
2. Swansea is eager to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement, former Derby manager, as the preferred candidate.
3. The unnamed speaker emphasizes the urgency to select a manager capable of preventing relegation, acknowledging the increasing strength of the Championship and the difficulty of earning immediate promotion back to the Premier League, as demonstrated by clubs like Norwich and Burnley.
4. The speaker notes that even if Swansea were to be relegated, returning to the Premier League would be challenging, especially in comparison to powerful clubs like Newcastle, which can retain top players.
5. Swansea's rise from near bankruptcy and potential relegation from the Football League to Premier League promotion in 2011 is highlighted, along with their reputation for playing attractive, possession-based football under managers like Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers, and Michael Laudrup.
6. Curtis, a former player and part of Swansea's ascent through the divisions, believes the club has lost its way since Laudrup's departure in 2014, attributing this to frequent managerial changes and the loss of key players without adequate replacement.
7. Despite these challenges, Curtis is confident in the current squad's ability to avoid relegation and stresses the importance of the club's history to new signings, some of whom have watched the documentary "Jack to a King" to understand Swansea's journey and the significance of staying in the Premier League for the club and its community.

The passage provides a summary of a match between Dagenham & Redbridge (the Daggers) and Leyton Orient (the O's) in League One, with significant implications for both teams. The Daggers needed a win to maintain their chances of avoiding relegation, but despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, they ultimately lost 3-2 after Armand Gnanduillet scored the winning goal for Orient. This result relegated Dagenham & Redbridge to the National League, a division they had previously ascended to for the first time in their history in 2007 under the management of John Still. The club's return to the National League comes after a period of struggle, marked by the worst goal difference in League Two and a significant increase in goals conceded compared to the previous season. Their attacking output has also diminished, with veteran striker Jamie Cureton's nine goals this season falling short of his previous tally of 20.

For Leyton Orient, the victory keeps their play-off aspirations alive, positioning them just two points outside the play-off zone. The win follows a tumultuous week that saw player-manager Kevin Nolan removed from his managerial role. Interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasized the team's professionalism and commitment to the fans despite the challenging circumstances.

John Still, who had returned to Dagenham for his third stint as manager in December, acknowledged his team's lack of organization and discipline, particularly in the first half of the match. He expressed his commitment to leading the Daggers back to promotion from the National League next season.

1. Steven Gerrard, former Liverpool captain and England international, is set to return to Liverpool in February as a youth coach. This will be his first coaching role since retiring from his playing career.
2. Jurgen Klopp, the current Liverpool manager, has expressed enthusiasm about Gerrard's appointment, noting that they had a detailed conversation. Klopp mentioned that Gerrard has expressed a desire to become a manager in the future.
3. Klopp emphasized the importance of understanding Gerrard's career aspirations and believes that Gerrard is prepared to start learning the managerial role, combining his extensive playing experience with new knowledge.
4. Gerrard's illustrious playing career with Liverpool included winning the Champions League, Uefa Cup, FA Cup, and League Cup (three times). He made his debut for the club in 1998 and left in 2015 to play for LA Galaxy in the MLS, retiring in November 2016 after a 19-year career.
5. Although Gerrard was linked to the managerial position at MK Dons, he felt the opportunity came too early in his coaching career.
6. Gerrard is currently working towards obtaining his Uefa A coaching license, which is a prerequisite for managing in the Premier League.

A concise summary of the passage:

In a football match, Morton took an early lead with McManus scoring from close range in the 15th minute. Their advantage was soon doubled by a deflected strike from Ross Forbes. Alloa reduced the deficit before half-time through a goal by Kyle McAusland. However, Morton secured a comfortable victory with McManus scoring again and Denny Johnstone adding a late goal.

1. Ofsted has discovered children being taught in poor conditions in three now-closed Birmingham locations.
2. Operators of illegal schools could face up to 51 weeks in jail.
3. The government is considering more regulation for educational settings teaching more than 6 to 8 hours a week.
4. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, reported inspectors' shock at the conditions found in these unregulated schools.
5. A total of 18 unregulated schools, primarily within Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been investigated recently.
6. Three Birmingham locations have been shut down due to suspicion of operating as illegal schools, with ongoing investigations into their owners.
7. Sir Michael expressed concern that the discovered cases may be a small part of a larger issue, with children potentially at risk of abuse or radicalization.
8. Educational settings operating more than 20 hours a week must register as schools; some "flexi schools" or part-time education centers operate legally, but there is concern that some are exploiting home education laws to run illegal schools.
9. Sir Michael criticized the education department for providing unhelpful advice to proprietors, delaying decisive action against the illegal schools.
10. The government has funded a team of inspectors to investigate illegal schools, with plans to extend scrutiny beyond Muslim communities to any group operating such unregistered centers.
11. The Education Secretary has committed to preparing prosecution cases against unregistered schools and emphasized that even one day spent in such a school is unacceptable.
12. Prosecution of unregistered schools requires the Education Secretary's consent, and a government consultation on further regulation is ongoing until mid-January.

1. Lilliard Gin is produced at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, Scotland.
2. The gin distillery is part of a resurgence in distilling in the region, with plans for the first whisky distillery since 1837.
3. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes expresses excitement about the potential for the Scottish Borders to become a region known for distilling excellence.
4. Lilliard Gin's production scale is smaller than other developing distilleries, with operations fitting into a cowshed and using one of the UK's smallest production stills.
5. The gin is crafted to reflect the local flavors and 'terroir' of the Teviot valley, utilizing abundant wild food from the area.
6. John Henderson of Born in the Borders highlights the synergy between the gin distillery and the existing Scottish Borders Brewery, emphasizing the shared commitment to local sourcing.
7. The name "Lilliard Gin" pays homage to a local heroine, Lilliard, who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545, and the gin's name also references the battle site, Lilliard's Edge.
8. The name choice for the gin reflects both the local landscape and the strong female team involved in its production.

51-year-old Gary Green from Bradburn Road, Wakefield, was convicted at Leeds Crown Court for causing the death of Harry Whitlam by reversing a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm in Rothwell, near Leeds, in August 2013. Green was found to be more than two times over the legal drinking limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before the incident. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, who worked at the farm's cafe, expressed the profound impact Harry's death has had on her family, emphasizing the gravity of driving under the influence, even on private land. Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in prison after pleading guilty to failing to ensure the safety of others. The case was prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law because the incident occurred on private property. An investigation by the Health and Safety Executive revealed that Green had reversed the tractor into Harry while he was walking towards a worker in a restricted area of the farm. HSE inspector Julian Franklin described the case as "extremely tragic" and Green's actions as "reckless."

1. Luis Suarez, a 27-year-old Uruguay striker, is now permitted to train and participate in friendly matches with his new club, Barcelona, following a partial lifting of his ban by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas).
