6. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey assures that both Newport County and Newport Squash Club, also at Rodney Parade, are protected by their current agreements, of which the WRU has been informed.
7. The WRU plans to install an artificial pitch, which conflicts with Football League regulations.
8. On the field, Newport County is two points above the League Two relegation zone with two games left, having won six of their last ten games under caretaker manager Mike Flynn. They have the chance to secure their league status with a win this weekend, coupled with a loss by Hartlepool.
9. Gavin Foxall states that relegation to the National League would be a significant setback for both the fans and the city of Newport, especially so soon after regaining Football League status in 2013.

The passage recounts the personal experiences of an individual in Sierra Leone who was kidnapped by rebels during the civil war that ended in 2002. At 15, he was forced to join the Revolutionary United Front (RUF), where he faced brutal initiation rituals, threats, and witnessed extreme violence. He managed to escape and, with the help of a preacher named Richard Cole, found hope and a purpose in rebuilding the nation. Richard Cole's project, Lifeline Nehemiah, provided him with education and support, instilling in him the importance of contributing to society.

When the Ebola crisis hit Sierra Leone in 2014, he and his team, despite not being medical professionals, were driven by a passion to make a difference. They engaged in three key activities: educating over 10,000 people about the reality of Ebola, providing food and support to thousands, and establishing an Ebola treatment unit in collaboration with other agencies. Their efforts saved many lives, even as they faced initial resistance and fear from the community.

The individual reflects on his transformation from a perpetrator of atrocities to a community leader, expressing regret for his past actions but optimism for the future. He emphasizes the importance of investing in young people to change the world.

The passage also provides statistics on the impact of the Ebola virus, with a total of 11,314 deaths across several countries, including Liberia (4,808), Sierra Leone (3,955), Guinea (2,536), and a smaller number in Nigeria. There was also one death in the US and six in Mali.

80,000 artifacts from the Wedgwood Museum, including art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs, were at risk of being auctioned to settle the pottery firm's pension debt. However, a public fundraising campaign successfully raised the necessary funds within a month of its launch in September. The collection, which had been under threat since the collapse of Waterford Wedgwood plc in 2009 and the subsequent administration of the museum in 2010, will now remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund, which spearheaded the campaign, will transfer ownership of the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, which will then loan it back to the Wedgwood Museum. Administrator Bob Young expressed satisfaction with the outcome, highlighting the complex negotiations and goodwill that made it possible. Alison Wedgwood, a descendant of the company's founder, emphasized the importance of the collection to Staffordshire and its near dispersal had the funds not been raised. Tristram Hunt MP celebrated the news, noting the collection's significance in charting Britain's cultural history and defining its national identity.

1. Dan Groves mentioned that details of a potential deal involving Wright purchasing a 20% stake in Billericay Town FC are still to be finalized.
2. According to The Sun, Wright, aged 30, is expected to join the club's board of directors.
3. Billericay Town FC currently sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off spot.
4. Wright has a background in non-league football, having played for teams such as Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds, and gained wider fame by finishing second on the reality TV show "I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here" in 2011.
5. The football club has recently seen a change in ownership with multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin taking over, expressing his willingness to invest significantly, around £10,000 a week, shortly after acquiring the club.
6. Billericay Town FC has also recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky, who is 35 years old, at the beginning of March.

The match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute with a goal from Jamille Matt, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized from a corner after 17 minutes through Kurtis Guthrie. Both teams had chances to take the lead, with Blackpool's Sam Slocombe making key saves, including one from George Elokobi on the brink of half-time, and Colchester's Guthrie hitting the bar from close range. Blackpool's Tom Aldred missed a header that could have secured the win. The match ended dramatically with Colchester's Sean Murray being sent off for a bad tackle in injury time, reducing Colchester to 10 men. Several bookings were issued to players from both teams throughout the match.

1. The Fawley power station chimney is set to become the tallest structure south of London's Shard as part of a redevelopment plan.
2. Fawley Waterside, the developers, intend to transform the area into a "merchant city" with the chimney as a central feature.
3. The power station, which closed in 2013 after over 40 years of operation, was commissioned in 1971 and had the capacity to power one million homes.
4. The proposed £1 billion development includes a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth.
5. The 300-acre site was purchased by Fawley Waterside in 2016.
6. The development plans include a petal-shaped glass structure, and an application for outline planning permission is expected later in the year, with construction potentially starting in 2018.
7. The 198-meter-high chimney, a prominent feature of the Solent skyline, is part of the 2,000-megawatt oil-fired power station, which was fueled by the nearby Esso refinery.
8. Aldred Drummond from Fawley Waterside emphasizes the chimney's value as a signature piece of infrastructure and suggests that with minimal investment, it can be transformed into a spectacular attraction, comparing it to other local landmarks like the i360 in Brighton and the Spinnaker Tower in Portsmouth.

23-year-old British cyclist Latham won a bronze medal in the men's points race at the Hong Kong championships, following Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. Latham managed to chase down Poland's Adrian Teklinski, who won gold, and Germany's Lucass Liss, who took silver. In other events, Great Britain's men's team pursuit settled for fourth place after being beaten by Italy for the bronze. Joe Truman, the only British rider in the men's keirin, was outperformed in his semi-final. The women's team pursuit saw Great Britain finish fifth in the heats, missing out on the bronze-medal ride. Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy praised Latham's strategic race and final sprint. Elinor Barker, part of the young women's team pursuit squad, expressed optimism about their future despite not medaling. The team, with an average age of 19, showed potential for the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. Katy Marchant, the only female sprinter from Great Britain, was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint but remains focused on her preparation for Tokyo.

1. Ross Kemp, who portrayed Grant Mitchell, will briefly return to the British soap opera "EastEnders" after last appearing in 2006.
2. His return is prompted by the departure of Dame Barbara Windsor, who plays Peggy Mitchell, the matriarch of the Mitchell family.
3. Peggy Mitchell's character, who had left the show in 2010, made a surprise return to announce her cancer had returned and that her character would be written out of the show.
4. Kemp's character, Grant Mitchell, will reunite with his family, including his brother Phil (played by Steve McFadden), as they face the impending death of their mother from cancer.
5. The emotional scenes of Peggy's death and the Mitchell family's reunion are expected to be significant episodes in the show's history.
6. Grant Mitchell's return is seen as a tribute to the character's legacy and the upcoming storyline is anticipated to feature strong performances from Kemp and McFadden.

1. Sadio Mane scored two goals in quick succession (138 seconds) against Tottenham Hotspur at Anfield.
2. Tottenham, who were in second place, had a poor start to the game, which their manager, Mauricio Pochettino, attributed to a lack of desire to win.
3. Chelsea has the opportunity to increase their lead at the top of the Premier League to 12 points if they win against Burnley.
4. Tottenham's away form has been poor, with only two wins since 24 September, and they have suffered defeats against Chelsea and Manchester United, as well as draws against Arsenal and Manchester City.
5. In their last 17 away games against other top-six teams, Tottenham have won only once.
6. Pochettino expressed that the first-half performance indicated that his team was not ready to compete for the Premier League title and that they struggled to handle the pressure.
7. Danny Murphy, a former player for Liverpool and Tottenham, criticized Tottenham's defensive performance, noting their usual strong defensive record. He suggested that their decision to play with a back four instead of a back three, which they typically use against big sides, contributed to their poor performance.
8. Murphy also pointed out Tottenham's lack of pace and a different mindset away from home, emphasizing the need for quick improvement.

1. The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 out of 28 governorships in the recent elections, marking the biggest loss for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999.
2. The PDP, which had previously lost the presidential election to APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, also lost governorships in key northern states such as Katsina and Kaduna, as well as in Adamawa, a state affected by Boko Haram's insurgency.
3. The PDP managed to retain control of Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, and won eight governorships, mainly in the south-east.
4. The election results are still pending for Taraba, and the election in Imo state was declared inconclusive due to a high number of spoilt ballots.
5. Elections were not conducted in seven states.
6. The APC's victory has significantly reduced the PDP's influence, transforming it into a regional party with limited support outside the south-east and Niger Delta.
7. Despite the APC's national success, they failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose challenges for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari in managing oil production and revenue.
8. The elections were generally more peaceful than previous years, although there were instances of violence, particularly in Rivers and other southern states.
9. The APC's victory in Lagos state is historically significant as it aligns the presidency and the commercial capital under the same party for the first time since 1999.
10. The PDP is expected to undergo a period of self-reflection and rebuilding following the loss, attributed to voter desire for change, internal defections, and allegations of corruption and inadequate response to the northern insurgency.

1. The Hebridean Celtic Festival is introducing an app that allows visitors to access online content by scanning items like signs and posters with their phones or tablets.
2. This content includes videos and band interviews.
3. The festival is happening in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19 to 22.
4. Performers at the festival include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean.
5. HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan stated that the augmented reality feature is intended to enhance the festival experience for attendees and also enable global interaction with the festival.
6. The app will provide up-to-date messages, allowing users to access information, interviews, and purchase tickets both before and during the event, giving a sense of the festival's atmosphere to people worldwide.

The passage discusses the potential termination of funding for several Birmingham academies due to inadequate Ofsted ratings and concerns over the promotion of a narrow, faith-based ideology. The schools in question are Park View, Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, and Golden Hillock School, all of which were rated inadequate by Ofsted. The Park View Educational Trust, which runs some of these schools, may be removed from their management. A head teacher at one of these schools, referred to as the "Trojan Horse" schools, reported feeling isolated and undermined by parents and considered quitting before the Trojan Horse letter's contents became public.

Ofsted's reports, published after inspecting 21 schools, found issues with the schools' ability to keep students safe from extremism, improper vetting of external speakers, and the promotion of spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development. Birmingham City Council plans to work with the Department for Education to establish a temporary governing board for Saltley School, the only local authority school placed in special measures.

Education minister Lord Nash expressed deep concerns about the management of Park View School and decided to terminate its funding agreement, with a similar decision for Nansen Primary School. Both schools were given until 4 July to respond. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were also warned about the potential termination of their funding agreements unless they addressed concerns such as ending less favorable treatment of non-Muslims, ceasing segregation of boys and girls, and ensuring a broader curriculum.

Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw highlighted a culture of fear and intimidation in Birmingham schools, while some head teachers reported an organized campaign to impose a narrow, faith-based ideology. Park View School plans to challenge the Ofsted report through legal channels. Parents and staff at Saltley School are focused on improving their Ofsted rating with the help of a new associate head teacher, despite accusations of bias in Ofsted's reports. Some parents have invited Education Secretary Michael Gove to discuss the findings and the evidence supporting them.

Vincent Barker, also known as Vinnie, passed away in July 2012, shortly after undergoing a standard eye examination at a Boots store in Ipswich. The prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court has charged Honey Rose, a 35-year-old eye specialist, with gross negligence manslaughter, claiming that her professional conduct was significantly below the required standard to the point of being criminal. Ms. Rose, who resides in Newham, east London, has pleaded not guilty to the charge.

The core of the prosecution's case is that Ms. Rose failed to identify signs of swollen optic discs during Vinnie's routine eye test, which should have prompted a referral for further medical investigation. This alleged oversight contributed to a fatal build-up of fluid in Vinnie's brain, leading to increased pressure within his skull and ultimately resulting in his death. The prosecution argues that Vinnie's death could have been prevented if Ms. Rose had fulfilled her professional duties competently. Given the severity of the outcome and the standards expected of a qualified optometrist, the prosecution deems her conduct to be criminally negligent. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into having sex with a man he connected her with through an adult website, and filming the encounters. He also sent a sexually explicit video of the woman to her sister on Christmas Day. The offenses occurred between September 2013 and September 2014. Weatherhogg was convicted after a trial at Dundee Sheriff Court and was placed on the sex offenders register. The case was referred to the High Court in Edinburgh due to its need for greater sentencing powers. Weatherhogg was considered a moderate risk of re-offending sexually. The victim felt blackmailed by Weatherhogg, and the judge, Lady Wolffe, emphasized the need for a sentence that reflected the gravity of the offense. Weatherhogg's defense counsel described his client's experience of being remanded in custody as a dramatic shock.

In a T20 match in Greater Noida, Ireland posted a total of 165-5, with Stuart Thompson contributing 56 runs and significant support from Gary Wilson (41 not out) and captain William Porterfield (39). Despite their efforts, Afghanistan achieved the target in the 18th over with Samiullah Shenwari scoring 56 and Mohammad Shahzad adding 47. The two teams are set to play the second T20 at the same venue. Ireland's innings started poorly with opener Paul Stirling out for a duck, but Thompson and Porterfield stabilized the innings. Porterfield acknowledged that Ireland fell short of a bigger score and struggled with bowling execution. Additionally, Ireland's pace bowler Boyd Rankin was unavailable for the T20 series due to a back injury but is expected to return for the upcoming five ODIs against Afghanistan starting on March 15.

1. Barcelona signed Neymar from Santos for £48.6m, with £34m of that fee going to his parents.
2. The total cost of Neymar's transfer, including fees and wages over a five-year contract, is £106.8m.
3. Barcelona's former president, Sandro Rosell, resigned amid accusations of misappropriating funds related to the transfer and is under investigation, though he denies wrongdoing.
4. Barcelona stated they had paid 57m euros for Neymar, but it was alleged the actual cost was higher when considering other contracts.
5. A Spanish judge found enough evidence to continue investigating the transfer.
6. Barcelona made an additional tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to address potential interpretations of their tax obligations, insisting they have committed no tax-related crime.
7. Neymar's performance for Barcelona this season includes seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches.
8. It remains unclear whether the case against Barcelona will be dropped following their additional tax payment.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a beach in Koh Tao on September 15. British police officers went to Thailand last month to assist in the investigation, which is being led by Thai police who are detaining two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21. These suspects are accused of murdering Miller and Witheridge and have allegedly confessed to the crimes, although there have been reports, which Thai police deny, that they later retracted their confessions. The suspects are facing charges of conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery, and they could be sentenced to death if convicted.

The UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns to the Thai authorities about the handling of DNA evidence and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects. Despite initial reluctance, the Thai Prime Minister agreed to allow a delegation of British police to review the investigation after meeting with UK Prime Minister David Cameron at a summit in Italy.

The Metropolitan Police have stated that the UK detectives have completed their review of the investigation to the extent possible and are now returning to the UK to compile a report and update the families of the victims. Post-mortem examinations revealed that Miller died from drowning and a head injury, while Witheridge died from head wounds, with Thai police claiming that DNA found on her body matches the suspects.

1. The Scottish women's football team has won all five of their qualifying matches and will secure their place in the upcoming tournament with a victory against Iceland at Falkirk Stadium.
2. Jane Evans, a player on the team, expresses the importance of qualifying this time, having missed out on Euro 2013 and the World Cup due to play-off losses.
3. Iceland, ranked just above Scotland at number 20 in the world, has also remained unbeaten in their qualifiers, making the upcoming matches between the two teams crucial for determining the group leader.
4. The top six runners-up from the qualifying groups will automatically qualify for the finals in the Netherlands next summer, and Scotland is currently well-positioned to qualify without a play-off.
5. The Scottish squad includes players from various top international leagues, with 12 of the 20 players, including Evans, playing outside Scotland.
6. Evans recently won the women's Bundesliga with Bayern Munich and highlights the positive impact of playing in competitive leagues abroad on the national team's performance.
7. The Scottish Women's Premier League is improving, but the experience gained by players in foreign leagues is seen as beneficial to the national team's success as they aim to reach their first major finals.

The passage discusses Apple's response to the unauthorized access of intimate celebrity photos from iCloud, which may have involved third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Apple has introduced a two-step verification process to enhance security, which requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device in addition to their password when logging in from a new device. This feature, while previously available, is now being more aggressively promoted by Apple, though it remains an opt-in service.

The two-step verification now extends to iCloud backups, previously a vulnerability that allowed attackers to download complete backups even if two-step verification was enabled for account access. Apple has also implemented email notifications for when backups are downloaded.

Vladimir Katalov, owner of Elcomsoft, acknowledges that Apple's changes have effectively countered his software's ability to access iCloud content. However, he raises concerns about the recovery key, which can be lost or stolen, potentially leading to data loss or unauthorized access.

Prof Alan Woodward from the University of Surrey suggests that two-factor authentication should be the default setting due to the vulnerabilities of single-step verification. Apple's CEO, Tim Cook, recognizes the need for increased awareness about security measures and plans to encourage users to adopt stronger passwords and two-factor authentication. The passage concludes with a broader statement about the responsibility of tech companies, including Apple, Microsoft, and Google, to prioritize user security by implementing two-factor authentication as a default setting.

1. UKIP won the May election and spent £2,956,737 on their campaign.
2. The Conservative Party spent £2,980,815 on their campaign, slightly more than UKIP.
3. The Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575 and lost all but one of their MEPs.
4. Labour came second in the election and spent £1,027,339 on their campaign.
5. The campaign spending figures are for the period from 23 January to polling day on 22 May.
6. UKIP's spending equated to 68p per vote, Labour's was 26p per vote, the Conservatives' was 79p per vote, and the Liberal Democrats' was £1.45 per vote.
7. The Green Party, which came fourth, spent £534,249, which is 43p per vote.
8. The six highest-spending parties, including the SNP at £267,372, spent a combined total of £9,347,087 on campaigning, according to the Electoral Commission.
9. All parties except Labour increased their campaign spending compared to the 2009 European election campaign.

27-year-old centre-back Anderson has mutually agreed to terminate his contract with Barrow to join another club in the National League. He has a background playing for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy, and may face his former team on 18 February. Additionally, 21-year-old striker Keating has been signed by Torquay United, managed by Kevin Nicholson, following a recommendation from former Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating's previous clubs include Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. His transfer is pending international clearance. Nicholson has described Anderson as a leader-type defender despite his limited game experience, and has expressed that Keating is a young and eager player. Torquay United, also known as the Gulls, are currently in a precarious position, four points above the relegation zone, with a recent record of only one win in their last six matches. For more information on football transfers, a dedicated page is available.

10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, despite having no significant underlying health issues. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) confirmed the cause of death as a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. Although rare, these incidents can occur in healthy sport horses, and the BHA is determined to understand and prevent such occurrences. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, characterized by overheating and unsteadiness, but not on the day of the race. He was a notable winner, having won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and was described by trainer Oliver Sherwood as the "horse of a lifetime." Despite past treatments for overheating, including after his Grand National victory, Many Clouds' welfare was closely monitored, and the report concludes that his death was due to the unexpected haemorrhage.

1. Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, was emotional during the farewell speeches of veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond, both of whom are standing down as MSPs ahead of the 5 May election.
2. Alex Salmond, who served as First Minister from 2007 to 2014, emphasized in his final speech that Scotland is diverse rather than divided and expressed the need for the Scottish Parliament to take on more responsibility for governing Scotland.
3. Salmond welcomed the additional powers granted to Holyrood through the Scotland Bill but noted that the bill did not fulfill the promises made by unionist politicians during the referendum campaign.
4. He made light-hearted comments about competing with the Chancellor's UK budget and the Cheltenham horse racing event for attention.
5. Salmond wished all candidates in the upcoming election well, with varying degrees of enthusiasm, and expressed that serving in the Scottish Parliament was the greatest honor in public life.
6. Tricia Marwick praised Salmond for his service to both the parliament and Scotland.
7. Duncan McNeil, who has been an MSP since the parliament's inception in 1999, warned in his final speech that Holyrood could learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure proper accountability and scrutiny.
8. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, joked about her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney and also announced her departure from Holyrood.

The passage provides information about the upcoming live-action film adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, with Dan Stevens as the Beast and Luke Evans as the antagonist Gaston. The role of Mrs Potts, originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version, will be played by an unnamed star. Kevin Kline will portray Maurice, Belle's father. Additionally, Josh Gad, known for voicing Olaf in "Frozen," is set to play Gaston's sidekick LeFou. The film is directed by Bill Condon and is scheduled to begin filming in May at Shepperton Studios, with a release date set for 17 March 2017 in U.S. cinemas.

1. The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to announce its decision on whether to bring charges related to the Hillsborough disaster at a meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST.
2. The disaster, which occurred in 1989 at an FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest, resulted in the fatal injury of 96 football fans.
3. Margaret Aspinall, whose son was among those who died, expressed hope that this announcement could mark the final step towards closure for the Hillsborough tragedy.
4. The announcement follows new inquests last year that concluded the fans were unlawfully killed.
5. In January, the CPS received files of evidence concerning 23 suspects, with 15 related to the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes and 8 related to an Independent Police Complaints Commission inquiry into the police response.
6. The meeting in Warrington will be private, with Sue Hemming from the CPS informing the relatives of the decisions.
7. Mrs. Aspinall, chairwoman of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, described the wait for the CPS decision as a "long, long struggle" and anticipates a day of mixed emotions for the families, who remain determined to seek accountability.

1. Chelmsford Prison has experienced multiple incidents of items being thrown over the prison wall.
2. A former prisoner described the facility as "notorious" for the influx of contraband, including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis.
3. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the efforts of staff to prevent the entry of contraband but emphasized the need for additional measures to address the issue.
4. A local resident reported witnessing packages being thrown over the prison wall four times in two weeks and mentioned an upcoming community meeting to discuss the situation.
5. Despite feeling safe, the resident takes precautions such as locking doors.
6. The former inmate alleged that drones were being used to deliver contraband directly to prison windows, although the Ministry of Justice denied any evidence of drones at Chelmsford Prison.
7. New laws have been enacted that could result in a two-year prison sentence for individuals caught smuggling items over prison walls.

72-year-old Sylvia Blackburn sustained severe head injuries after being struck by a car driven by Brian Wright, 55, near Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, who is from Kempston, claims he was blinded by the setting sun at the time of the incident and has expressed remorse for his actions, acknowledging the impact on Mrs. Blackburn and her family. Despite his emotional statement, he denies the charge of causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn, a lollipop lady known for her 20 years of service, was on duty in her reflective clothing when she was hit while helping a woman and her child cross the road. The prosecutor stated that Wright's VW Golf did not stop for a red light, although Wright himself cannot recall the color of the traffic signal at the time. The court heard that the sun could have impaired Wright's vision, and the trial is ongoing. Mrs. Blackburn is currently receiving care in a residential facility.

24-year-old Scottish middle distance runner Laura Muir has announced that she will not be able to compete for Scotland at the 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her final year veterinary medicine studies. Her exams are scheduled for May, which clashes with the timing of the Games in April. Despite her disappointment at missing the opportunity to represent Scotland, Muir is prioritizing her education and is determined to complete her degree. She expressed her love for running for Scotland and her belief that the Scottish team will perform well at the Commonwealth Games.

Muir has had a successful athletic career, finishing fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. She is optimistic about her future in athletics, aiming for at least two or three more Olympics, although she is uncertain about which events she will target.

Looking ahead, Muir is considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential goal, but she acknowledges that the next few months will be intense as she balances her studies with training. She is pleased with her performance at the World Championships, where she set a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m with a time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds, despite it being her fifth race in 10 days. Muir is confident about her potential for future competitions.

22-year-old Trevor Deely was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search operation began early on a Saturday morning in Chapelizod, Dublin, at a three-acre woodland site adjacent to the R112 road leading to the River Liffey. The search, which includes excavations, is expected to last several weeks. Prior to the search, a team of six detectives conducted a comprehensive review of the case. Enhanced CCTV footage from the night of Deely's disappearance showed him talking to a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where Deely worked. It is believed Deely was retrieving an umbrella after the party. The enhanced footage was released in April, and police appealed for the man to come forward, as they suspect he followed Deely later on Haddington Road. Despite the appeal, the man in the footage has not been identified, prompting authorities to renew their call for his cooperation with the investigation.

1. Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th due to injury absences, defeated Stan Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 in the second round of a Grand Slam, his first since the 2014 Australian Open.
2. Del Potro, a former US Open champion and Wimbledon semi-finalist, is in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray and could face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young in the next round.
3. The 27-year-old Argentine has undergone three wrist operations and expressed his gratitude for the support he has received, feeling rejuvenated after a difficult period.
4. Nick Kyrgios, the 15th seed, also in Murray's half, overcame Dustin Brown in a five-set match that was interrupted by rain, advancing to face Feliciano Lopez in the third round.
5. Lopez, the 22nd seed, achieved a comeback win against Fabio Fognini, while other seeded players Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga progressed with straight-set victories.

Tunisia narrowly avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to the Confederation of African Football (Caf) for complaints they made during the 2015 tournament. The controversy arose when Tunisia was awarded a disputed penalty in the quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea, leading to a loss after extra time. Tunisia's football federation clarified that they did not accuse Caf or the referee of corruption but criticized the referee's performance and selection. The issue was resolved following a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou, ensuring Tunisia's participation in the 2017 qualifiers.

Morocco's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup qualifiers was secured after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned their ban and reduced their fine. Morocco had been banned from the 2015 and 2017 tournaments for refusing to host the 2015 event due to Ebola concerns, requesting a postponement instead. Fouzi Lekjaa, the Moroccan FA chief, expressed optimism for the future of Moroccan and African football, downplaying the impact of the ban. Equatorial Guinea replaced Morocco as the 2015 hosts with just 64 days to prepare.

Both Tunisia and Morocco are now preparing for the 2017 Nations Cup qualifiers, with Tunisia aiming for their first win since 2004 and looking to set a record by reaching their thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup if they qualify for the finals in Gabon. Tunisia is grouped with Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

The passage provides a historical overview of McLaren's trajectory in Formula 1 (F1), highlighting their past successes and current challenges. McLaren has an impressive record with 182 grand prix wins, a 23.18% win rate, 12 drivers' world championships, and 8 constructors' titles. Despite their current struggles, they boast two world champions in their lineup, including Fernando Alonso, who is considered by some to be the best driver on the grid.

McLaren's decline began in 2013 due to issues with chassis design, compounded by problems with the Honda power-unit. This contrasts with their previous successes, particularly in the late 1980s and 1990s, when they dominated F1, winning 15 out of 16 races in 1988 with drivers Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost. They experienced a resurgence in 1998-99 with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes engines, securing their last constructors' title in 1998.

The team faced setbacks in 2007 and 2009 due to scandals, including being stripped of their constructors' championship and a $100m fine for possessing Ferrari's technical information, and the 'lie-gate' scandal, respectively. Despite occasional race wins, titles eluded them after 1999, with the exception of Lewis Hamilton's championship in 2008.

McLaren's history has been characterized by cycles of triumph and decline, with their first decade focused on building a competitive team. They achieved their first title in 1974 with Emerson Fittipaldi and another in 1976 with James Hunt. A significant downturn followed, prompting Ron Dennis to take control and lead them to dominance in the 1980s and 1990s.

Despite their current predicament, McLaren's leadership, including Ron Dennis, remains optimistic, believing that success will return and that they will challenge Mercedes' dominance in F1. Fernando Alonso's return to McLaren in 2015 was based on his faith in the team's potential to win another title, particularly with the Honda partnership. The team is confident that their car is competitive and that Honda will improve their engine, expecting to deliver multiple championships in the future. However, as of now, they are in a period of belief and anticipation, with much at stake for both the team's legacy and Alonso's career.

1. Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 due to a sudden death.
2. Police found patrons still at the bar when they arrived, with evidence of alcohol being served until 04:49 BST.
3. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both of Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside of licensing hours.
4. The defense acknowledged that the licensing laws were not followed and the bar was not properly managed, staying open into the morning.
5. The judge ordered Joe's Bar to close for three months, fined Ms. O'Neill £3,000, and fined Mr. Thomas £1,000.
6. Ms. O'Neill, the license holder, was noted to have "an appalling record," and the judge expressed regret over the lack of power to impose a custodial sentence.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 comeback win over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry, who needed four 3-pointers to surpass his previous record of 272, set in the 2012-13 season, made eight three-pointers in the game. He also contributed nine assists, while Klay Thompson added 26 points to help the Warriors avoid a three-game losing streak. The Trail Blazers, led by LaMarcus Aldridge with 27 points and Damian Lillard with 20 points and eight assists, have already secured their division title.

In other NBA action, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, significantly impacting Miami's playoff prospects. Pau Gasol led the Bulls with 16 points and 15 rebounds, while Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson each scored 14 points. The Bulls outscored the Heat 57-27 in the second half, with Miami missing its first 12 shots after the break. Derrick Rose contributed 12 points for Chicago, which reclaimed the third spot in the Eastern Conference standings. Hassan Whiteside was a standout for the Heat with 19 points and 16 rebounds, but Dwyane Wade had a tough night, scoring only nine points on 4-for-20 shooting.

A YouTube star, Bas van Velzen, known for his free-kick skills, surprised Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic at their training ground, Melwood. The players initially believed they were meeting an ordinary competition winner for a free-kick masterclass. However, they soon realized van Velzen was an expert free-kick taker when he demonstrated his impressive dead-ball abilities, even scoring a goal past the stand-in goalkeeper. Balotelli also took part, initially struggling but then successfully executing a free-kick. Van Velzen expressed his excitement about meeting Balotelli and the other players, and he enjoyed pretending to be less skilled than he was to surprise the players with his talent. The experience was a dream come true for van Velzen, and he concluded the day by revealing a t-shirt with Balotelli's famous slogan, referencing the iconic moment from Balotelli's time at Manchester City.

The passage discusses the benefits of oophorectomy (removal of the ovaries) for women with breast cancer who carry the BRCA1 gene mutation, similar to the situation of actress Angelina Jolie. Key points include:

1. Women with the BRCA1 gene mutation can significantly reduce their risk of dying from breast cancer by having an oophorectomy, with a study showing a more than 60% decrease in breast cancer death rates.
2. Angelina Jolie, a BRCA1 carrier, underwent an oophorectomy in March and a double mastectomy two years prior to reduce her cancer risk.
3. The study, conducted in Canada, analyzed 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations and found that those who had an oophorectomy after diagnosis had a 77.4% 20-year survival rate, with a 62% reduction in breast cancer deaths for BRCA1 carriers.
4. The protective effect of oophorectomy was immediate and lasted for 15 years, with a 73% reduction in death for BRCA1 carriers who had the surgery within two years of diagnosis.
5. Oophorectomy also reduced the risk of death from all causes by 65% and prevented ovarian cancer deaths in the study group.
6. The study suggests that oophorectomy should be considered part of the treatment discussion for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer.
7. The procedure was particularly beneficial for women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer.
8. BRCA1 carriers have a 50% to 80% risk of developing breast cancer in their lifetime, with the mutation being more common in the Ashkenazi Jewish population.
9. Genetic tests are available for women with a significant family history of breast cancer to detect BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, and PTEN gene mutations.
10. Angelina Jolie shared that the procedure did not diminish her sense of femininity or womanliness.

The passage emphasizes the importance of considering oophorectomy as a treatment option for BRCA1 mutation carriers diagnosed with breast cancer, as it significantly improves survival rates and reduces the risk of death from the disease.

A married couple, Derek and Tina Lowe, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train in Durham, North Carolina on Easter Sunday morning. The incident occurred around 10 am as the couple lingered on the tracks. The train, Amtrak's Carolinian No. 80, was en route from Charlotte to New York City and was traveling on property owned by Norfolk-Southern at the time of the accident. None of the 166 passengers aboard the train were injured, although one man fell ill during the subsequent delay and received treatment. The train resumed its journey after a delay of approximately two hours and 45 minutes. It was reported that the Lowes may have been living in a homeless camp, according to a man who had met them while collecting scrap metal. The man, James Thompson, recalled an interaction with the couple, who had asked for assistance crossing the railroad tracks with their grocery cart. The accident resulted in a delay of almost three hours for the train, which was scheduled to travel to Raleigh, about 25 miles from Durham, and then continue to New York City, a trip that typically takes about 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for the promise of US citizenship. After fleeing Colombia in the 1980s due to a confrontation with his boss, he sought refuge in the US and began providing information on his former associates to the DEA. Toro, now 66, was a crucial asset to the DEA, aiding in significant operations and the prosecution of notorious figures such as Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega. Despite his service, he has not been granted citizenship and is facing deportation after retiring due to health issues. The DEA has refused to assist him with his citizenship application after he publicized his situation. Toro fears for his life if deported to Colombia and is currently living in the US illegally. His former handler, DEA agent Mike McManus, has criticized the government's inaction and provided Toro with financial assistance for medical care. Toro is currently without legal status in the US, unable to collect social security benefits, and is at risk of being forced into hiding as his final temporary visa has expired. He remains in limbo, seeking a green card or passport, and emphasizes that all he wants is the citizenship that was promised to him.

1. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is scrutinizing Vox Populi Registry Ltd., a Canadian company, for its use of the '.sucks' domain name. Vox Populi has been selling '.sucks' domains to trademark holders and celebrities, including Kevin Spacey and companies like YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo, at high prices.
2. Kevin Spacey and other celebrities have reportedly paid to have their associated '.sucks' domains taken down. Taylor Swift has also previously spent money to protect her reputation from '.adult' domains.
3. ICANN initially approved the '.sucks' top-level domain along with nearly 600 others to expand beyond common domain names. However, after complaints from an advisory panel representing industry groups and companies, ICANN is reconsidering its position.
4. Vox Populi has been charging $2,499 a year for '.sucks' domains, with most names sold by resellers for around $2,000 a year. The company's CEO, John Berard, defends the practice as a means for companies to engage with critics and as compliant with ICANN rules and the law.
5. The advisory panel has labeled the '.sucks' domain rollout a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory," urging ICANN to halt it. They argue that the high prices and the threat of these domains becoming available to the public are coercive.
6. ICANN has reached out to the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to investigate the legality of Vox Populi's actions. If found illegal, ICANN may declare the company in breach of contract and seek to change its behavior. ICANN is also exploring other remedies within its agreement with Vox Populi.
7. Currently, '.sucks' domains are available for trademark holders and celebrities, with plans to offer them to the public for $10 a year starting in September. The advisory body believes that the prospect of a '.sucks' site being opened to the average consumer is a key part of Vox Populi's coercive strategy.

27 years after the body of a baby boy was found in a Sainsbury's bag floating on a village pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, the mother of the child was identified through DNA evidence. The baby, who was stillborn, was placed in the pond by his mother, who had concealed her pregnancy from family and friends. The case was revisited as part of a periodic review, leading to the exhumation of the baby's body and the eventual DNA match. Initially arrested on suspicion of infanticide, the charge was dropped when the mother explained the circumstances of the stillbirth. The baby was reburied at the same church where he was originally interred, and the mother remains on bail pending a decision by the Crown Prosecution Service on charges related to failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial. The investigation, which utilized advanced DNA techniques, brought closure to a long-standing mystery and evoked mixed emotions among the investigators, who expressed empathy for the mother's plight. The baby, named Peter after the church, now has a proper headstone paid for by a support group for parents of stillborn children.

27-year-old Kristopher Hicks was severely brain-injured after jumping from a taxi driven by Michael Young, who mistakenly thought Hicks was going to leave without paying. Hicks was on a night out with his girlfriend in Bath, Somerset, when the incident occurred. Young, a former soldier, attempted to teach Hicks a lesson by driving him back to the taxi rank, but Hicks jumped out of the moving vehicle, which was traveling at over 20mph, resulting in his injuries. Hicks now requires constant care from his mother and has developed epilepsy.

Hicks' family took Young to the High Court, where Mr. Justice Edis ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages. The compensation amount is yet to be finalized but is expected to be around 50% of what the family sought, likely hundreds of thousands of pounds. The judge acknowledged the severity of Hicks' injuries and the need for a settlement to fund his rehabilitation and care. Despite Young's intention not to harm Hicks, his actions created a significant risk, leading to the reduction of damages by 50% and an additional £250 for unlawful imprisonment. Both parties have been granted the right to appeal, and a future hearing will determine the exact compensation Young must pay.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night as severe storms, which included reports of tornadoes, affected the area. A tornado was spotted near Goddard, northwest of Wichita, and moved northeast, bypassing Wichita but potentially threatening other communities. Additional tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas, including near Aetna, 125 miles from Wichita. The severe weather was not confined to Kansas; a possible tornado was indicated in Potosi, Missouri, with reports of wind damage, flooding, and fallen trees. Nearby, residents in Leadington captured images of unusual dark clouds, and in Farmington, large hail was reported. The National Weather Service forecasted more storms for Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and areas near the southern Great Lakes. The report on the storms was contributed to by CNN's Sean Morris and Anneclaire Stapleton.

Luke Rockhold is preparing to confront Lyoto Machida with an aggressive approach, likening himself to a bull to Machida's matador, in their upcoming middleweight fight in New Jersey. Rockhold is aiming for his fourth consecutive win and a potential title shot. He plans to dominate Machida by cutting off the ring, pressuring him, and forcing him to fight on Rockhold's terms. Rockhold has analyzed Machida's fights and believes he has identified weaknesses he can exploit. He considers himself a well-rounded mixed martial artist and is confident in his abilities to outperform Machida both on the feet and on the ground.

Machida, on the other hand, is also confident in his strategy and technique, believing that he can defeat Rockhold and earn a title shot. Despite acknowledging a recent fight that could have determined the next title contender, Machida believes that the winner of his bout with Rockhold should be next in line. He has prepared extensively for the fight, including training with high-level fighters like Glover Teixeira, and feels ready and calm.

Both fighters have respect for each other's skills and fighting styles, but are determined to showcase their own abilities and secure victory in the upcoming clash.

A light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar plane, was captured on video making a belly landing at the Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida. The plane approached the runway without deploying its landing gear, resulting in a skid along the tarmac upon touchdown. The impact caused the propellers to ricochet off the ground and the wings to bounce. The pilot, identified as Chris Georgaklis, managed to re-engage the engines and take off again, despite the damaged propellers and the high angle of attack. Georgaklis, an experienced pilot of nearly 50 years, then flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale with his dog, Buddy, and landed safely. The most common causes for such gear-up landings are human error or mechanical failure. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is investigating the incident.

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment with Yaya Toure's performance this season but has pledged to support the Manchester City midfielder until the end of the season. Despite rumors that Manchester City is open to offers for Toure due to an aging squad and a faltering campaign, Pellegrini has dismissed the idea that Toure needs a break and has confirmed that the player will remain backed by him. Toure, who has a lucrative contract running for another two years, has been criticized for his role in the team's struggles, including the collapse of their Premier League title defense.

Pellegrini's own future at Manchester City is in question, but goalkeeper Joe Hart has voiced the players' support for the manager, emphasizing that the team has let Pellegrini down and that the players feel responsible for their subpar performances. Manchester City, currently struggling for form, will face West Ham without their captain Vincent Kompany, who may miss the remainder of the season due to injury.

In related news, West Ham's left-back Aaron Cresswell has attracted interest from Chelsea and Manchester City, prompting West Ham manager Sam Allardyce to caution Cresswell against making a hasty move, citing the examples of Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, who joined Manchester City but saw limited playing time. Allardyce suggests that players like Cresswell, who are attractive prospects due to their performance and ability to fulfill homegrown player quotas, should consider the potential trade-off between money and playing time when considering a transfer to a bigger club.

Domenico Rancadore, a fugitive member of the Sicilian mafia known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will be allowed to remain in the UK after his sentence was effectively nullified. Rancadore, who had been living in Britain for over 20 years, was originally sentenced to seven years in prison by an Italian court in 1999 for his association with the Cosa Nostra. Despite losing his battle against extradition in February, it was discovered that his case had expired last October due to Italian law, which states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed.

Although his conviction remains, the Italian Court of Appeal agreed to extinguish Rancadore's conviction on the grounds that it was too old to sustain a prison sentence. His lawyer, Karen Todner, expressed confidence that the Italian government would withdraw the European Arrest Warrant and that Rancadore would be discharged from the proceedings. The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) confirmed that the case would still need to be heard by the Italian Supreme Court.

Rancadore, also known as "The Professor," was arrested in 2013 at his London home and was wanted by Italian authorities for fleeing in 1995. He was convicted in absentia for his role as a "man of honour" in taking bribes from builders in Palermo. His extradition proceedings were protracted, with concerns about his human rights due to a serious heart condition.

Legal experts criticized the time and money spent on the case, especially after it was revealed that the Italian authorities could not legally enforce the sentence as of October 2014. The CPS admitted to a mistake by failing to serve appeal papers on time, which may have contributed to the delay that allowed Rancadore's sentence to expire. Despite the controversy, Rancadore will not be extradited and is expected to continue living in the UK with his family.

1. Mr Mole, ridden by A.P. McCoy, is one of three co-favourites at 7-2 for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday.
2. The Paul Nicholls-trained Mr Mole is joint favourite alongside Irish contender Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville as Barry Geraghty is injured.
3. A.P. McCoy will ride Mr Mole in what will be his last ride in a Grade One race, as he is set to retire.
4. McCoy's full schedule of rides for his final day as a professional jockey will be confirmed on Friday morning.
5. Mr Mole's victory at Newbury in February was the race after which McCoy announced his retirement plans.
6. Other horses running in the Celebration Chase include Somersby, trained by Mick Channon.

40 years after the murder of her daughter Marcia, Virginia Trimble Ritter recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body, which she had previously avoided seeing at the advice of her then-husband. Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sidney Barrett in 1975, and her body was found 33 days after her disappearance. Despite Barrett's conviction 33 years later and a sentence of 44 years imposed in 2009, Ritter's decision to view the photos last year led to a visceral reaction; she expressed a desire for revenge upon seeing the graphic images of her daughter's brutalized body. Marcia's murder remained unsolved for decades, with an initial suspect, a neighbor who was 15 at the time, charged and then released due to lack of evidence. Barrett, who had a history of sex charges and had been in and out of prison, was eventually linked to the crime through DNA evidence after his arrest for another murder.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one golfer, is determined to win the Masters at Augusta National to achieve the career grand slam, a feat accomplished by only five other players in history. The 25-year-old considers his final-round collapse at the 2011 Masters, where he led by four shots but finished with an 80, as a pivotal learning experience that propelled him to win his first major at the U.S. Open shortly after. McIlroy has since won three more majors and views the Masters as a significant milestone in his career. He believes that winning at Augusta would solidify his status as a complete player, capable of conquering different golf courses and conditions. Despite only one top-10 finish at the Masters, McIlroy is confident in his ability to win multiple green jackets and considers it almost unthinkable not to win at least one in his career. He plans to use the golf course as a sanctuary to escape the pressure and hype surrounding the event, as he did during his successful 2014 season despite personal and legal distractions. McIlroy is focused on playing his best at the upcoming Masters, hoping to join the exclusive group of golfers who have won all four major titles.

1. Four rainbows were spotted in the New York sky after heavy rainfall, captured by Amanda Curtis, CEO of a fashion company.
2. In rural China, the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes is becoming more common, but this is being targeted in the country's crackdown on vice.
3. Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during a Channel 4 interview when questioned about his private life.
4. The #KylieJennerChallenge, where people plump their lips by sucking on a jar to emulate Kylie Jenner's look, has become a trending topic on social media.
5. 102-year-old Alice Barker enjoyed a trip down memory lane with the help of filmmakers.
6. A controversial prom-posal referencing bombs led to accusations of racism against school administrators who disapproved.
7. Ewan McGregor has been cast as Lumiere in the upcoming 'Beauty and the Beast' film, generating significant social media interest.
8. Johnny Depp's transformation for his role in the 'Black Mass' trailer has left him nearly unrecognizable.
9. A creative pregnancy announcement referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad's photobomb of his son also gained attention for originality.
10. These stories were among the trending topics of the week.

272 youngsters in England were hospitalized in the past year due to disabilities caused by fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), a condition resulting from exposure to alcohol in the womb. This figure is considered to be the tip of the iceberg, as experts believe the actual number of children affected is much higher. The World Health Organization (WHO) research indicates that at least one in every 100 babies born in the UK may suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to prenatal alcohol exposure, which could mean around 7,500 affected babies annually.

Elizabeth Mitchell from the National Organization for Fetal Alcohol Syndrome emphasizes the severity and under-diagnosis of the condition, noting that children with FAS do not improve over time. A case in point is 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who requires assistance with daily activities, lacks a sense of danger, and will never live independently due to FAS. Her adoptive parents noticed developmental issues when she was three and she was diagnosed at age five.

FAS can lead to a range of medical issues, including liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. Current government advice is for pregnant women to limit alcohol consumption to no more than two units, up to twice a week, but there are calls for the guidance to be revised to recommend complete abstinence from alcohol during pregnancy.

31-year-old Shaun Andrew McKerry, known in his youth as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy" for his tendency to return home after committing crimes, attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15. Masked and armed with an axe, he threatened assistant Andrea Brighty, but was tackled by the shop's owner, Sab Dhillon. During the struggle, Dhillon's wife, Sam, hit McKerry with a baseball bat, striking him twice and helping to disarm him. The incident was captured on camera, with McKerry's face being revealed during the scuffle. He was arrested by police and later pleaded guilty to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court. McKerry was sentenced to six years in prison. His criminal history dates back to the age of 12, with a record of numerous arrests and convictions for various offenses, including shoplifting, aggravated vehicle-taking, sending indecent letters, and burglary.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow, Craig Stoner, Simon Radford, and Darren Smalley—have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman in her early 20s at a party at the Shearwater Naval Base in Nova Scotia, Canada. The incident allegedly occurred on April 10 after the sailors returned from a hockey game. The victim, a resident of Halifax, had accompanied a friend to the party, which was attended by local Canadian servicemen.

The four men appeared in a Dartmouth courtroom near Halifax, where they were granted bail under strict conditions. Each sailor's bail was set at over £2,000, and they were required to surrender their passports, live at the nearby Stadacona Naval Base, and remain in Nova Scotia. They are also forbidden from contacting the victim or six witnesses and must not leave the province or apply for new passports. Additionally, they must continue their employment with the Royal Navy and cannot resign without court permission.

The sailors, who had been playing for the Royal Navy ice hockey team, were ordered to return to court on May 27. The charges they face, sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, carry potential prison sentences of up to 14 years. The investigation is ongoing, and further forensic test results could lead to additional charges.

The British High Commission's Air and Naval Advisor, Commander Michael O'Sullivan, has described the allegations as serious but emphasized that they are still only allegations. The Royal Navy is assisting Canadian authorities with the investigation and will decide how to employ the accused sailors while their legal proceedings are underway.

Valerie Jackson, a mother from Las Vegas, has a four-year-old son named RJ Jackson who suffers from Netherton's Syndrome, a rare skin condition that affects only 70 people worldwide. The condition causes RJ's skin to appear red, inflamed, and scaly, often mistaken for burns or abuse. Valerie regularly applies creams to manage RJ's skin dryness and discomfort.

Despite her efforts to care for her son, Valerie has faced public accusations of child abuse, including an incident where armed police confronted her while shopping with RJ due to a report from a stranger. She also endures verbal abuse from people in the street who accuse her of harming RJ. The family has been denied access to public places like play centers, and RJ has been subjected to bullying, mostly from adults.

Netherton's Syndrome is a form of ichthyosis, characterized by red, scaly skin that can lead to heat, water, and protein loss, as well as increased risk of infection. The condition is genetic and can appear without a family history, with symptoms typically present at birth. While there is no cure, symptoms often improve with age, though the skin may remain sensitive and itchy.

Valerie discovered RJ's diagnosis through an online support group after struggling to find information about his symptoms. The group, which included parents of another child with Netherton's Syndrome, provided valuable advice on managing the condition. Despite the challenges, Valerie remains dedicated to her son's care and is hopeful that awareness and understanding of his condition will grow as he gets older. She sees beyond his skin condition and focuses on the beauty and joy of her son.

The passage describes the controversy surrounding Protein World's "Are you beach body ready?" advertising campaign, which featured a bikini-clad model named Renee Somerfield. The campaign, particularly the posters displayed across the London Underground, sparked significant backlash from feminists, body image campaigners, and the general public. A Change.org petition to remove the ads garnered over 50,000 signatures, and the Advertising Standards Authority received more than 200 complaints claiming the ads promoted an unhealthy body image.

Transport for London (TFL) announced the removal of the posters, citing the end of the three-week advertising period that Protein World had paid for. Despite the controversy, Protein World defended the campaign, stating the image was unphotoshopped and that they were targeting health-conscious individuals. The company also engaged with critics on social media, sometimes with confrontational responses.

The campaign was widely discussed on social media, with many users expressing outrage over the perceived message that women need to look a certain way to wear a bikini. TV presenter Susanna Reid described the campaign as "anxiety inducing" during an interview with Protein World's head of global marketing, Richard Staveley, who argued that the company's goal was to encourage fitness and health.

Despite threats and a bomb scare reported to the police, Protein World declared the campaign a success and stated they would not change their advertising approach. The Advertising Standards Authority was assessing the complaints to determine if further action was necessary. The passage also notes the growing market for protein powder in the UK, with sales expected to rise significantly by 2017.

Public figures such as Katie Hopkins and Samantha Brick weighed in on the debate, with Hopkins criticizing those who vandalized the ads and Brick expressing that the ad motivated her to be "bikini ready."

1. Rail companies plan to increase fares by up to 87% shortly after the general election, despite party leaders promising to freeze prices.
2. Prime Minister David Cameron has asked First Great Western (FGW) to urgently review its decision to nearly double some fares on the London to Cotswolds route, which affects his Witney constituency.
3. Cameron and the Labour party have pledged to freeze or cap fare increases.
4. FGW's fare hike would affect passengers traveling from Charlbury to London, raising the cost of an off-peak return ticket by 87% to £62.40.
5. Train companies can raise "unregulated" fares, which include off-peak and advance-purchase tickets, three times a year and these fares account for about half of their revenue.
6. FGW justifies the increase by aligning the North Cotswolds route fares with other services and offers cheaper advanced single tickets.
7. Other significant fare increases include a London Midlands first-class single from Crewe to Northampton and a Virgin anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool.
8. Virgin claims most of its price hikes are on "Virgin trains-only fares," which are 20% cheaper than competitors, and its overall fare increase is 1.65%, below the industry average.
9. Mike Richardson of Trainsplit.com notes that passengers may be surprised by the fare increases given the political promises of price freezes.
10. The research indicates that "anytime" and "off-peak" returns have risen by 40%, with increases seen in day-of tickets and on rural routes.

66-year-old John Young, a former soldier and retired HGV driver, was severely injured when thugs threw a brick through his front door in Oldham, Greater Manchester. Young, who is now blind in one eye, was at home with his wife Elaine, 54, when the attack occurred on April 18. The couple, who had recently married and were writing thank you cards for their wedding gifts, were subjected to a random act of violence as the vandals pelted stones at their living room window and then at the front door after Young went to confront them. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save the sight in his left eye. The police are investigating the incident, which appears to have no motive and may have been a case of youths "messing around." The attack has left the couple feeling unsafe in their neighborhood, and they are planning to move to Southport. Detective Constable Gareth Gwilliam of Greater Manchester Police has appealed to the public for information to help find those responsible for the senseless act that left Mr. Young with a permanent disability.

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old wicketkeeper for Derbyshire, has signed a new one-year contract extension with the club, keeping him there until the end of the 2016 season. This comes after his successful return from a leg injury sustained in a road accident last April, which also tragically resulted in the death of his father, Keith. Despite missing the entire 2014 season, Poynton underwent ankle operation and made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi. Graeme Welch, Derbyshire's Elite Performance Director, praised Poynton's exceptional character and work ethic during his recovery, expressing the club's delight at his return and hope that the new contract will allow him to play confidently in the upcoming season. Welch also noted Poynton's good form since his return to training and during the Abu Dhabi tour.

5-year-old Harley Renshaw has been declared cancer-free after a year-long battle with an aggressive form of neuroblastoma, which affected his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. Harley's journey included 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, surgery to remove a kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy at the Christie Clinic in Manchester. His bravery was recognized with a Little Star Award from Cancer Research UK, and he became the face of the charity's Kids and Teens campaign.

Harley found strength and courage by wearing a superhero costume and decorating his radiotherapy mask like a Ninja Turtle, which caught the attention of hospital staff and the children's TV channel Nickelodeon, who sent him a box of Ninja Turtle presents for Christmas. Neuroblastoma is a rare cancer affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK annually, primarily those under five. It is the second most common solid tumor in childhood and can spread to various parts of the body. Harley's parents, Oliver and Stacey, are overjoyed with the news of his recovery, and he is expected to return to school full-time. For more information or to donate to childhood cancer research, one can visit the Cancer Research UK Kids & Teens website.

1. Tim Sherwood advises Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old Aston Villa player, to prioritize his club career over his international future amidst a competition between the Republic of Ireland and England for his allegiance.
2. Grealish has impressed in Aston Villa's FA Cup semi-final victory over Liverpool, catching the attention of both national teams.
3. Sherwood emphasizes that Grealish must continue to secure his place in the Aston Villa first team, stating that it is his priority to ensure Grealish has the opportunity to make an international decision.
4. Grealish's performance against Liverpool, where he showcased his dribbling skills and confidence on the ball, has made him a subject of interest for both countries.
5. Sherwood compares Grealish's situation to that of Nabil Bentaleb, who chose to play for Algeria over France, and advises Grealish to follow his heart when making his decision.
6. Grealish is expected to make his choice between Ireland and England at the end of the season, and he is currently torn between the two.
7. Grealish's father, Kevin, supports the advice that his son should focus on his club performances, as international opportunities will follow if he continues to play well for Aston Villa.
8. There is a possibility that Grealish could play for both Ireland and England in an upcoming friendly, potentially featuring for 45 minutes for each team.
9. Although Grealish has previously played for the Republic of Ireland's youth teams, England is also vying to persuade him to switch allegiances.
10. Tim Sherwood celebrates Aston Villa's win over Liverpool and encourages Grealish to maintain his level of performance for the club.

The passage discusses the significant variation in landing fees at airports for private jets, which is a concern for the wealthy individuals who travel by private jet. These fees provide insight into unexpectedly popular transport hubs among the rich and famous, including locations like Salzburg in Austria and Darwin in Australia. The private jet industry is lucrative, with 2.5 million private flights recorded in the U.S. and 705,000 in Europe, and is valued at $16.7 trillion in the U.S. and $15.8 trillion in Europe. Demand surges during major sporting events, such as the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix, leading to higher costs for private jet travel.

Private jet companies have quoted high prices for travel to such events, with round-trip costs from New York to the Super Bowl reaching around $38,000 to $54,000. For the Monaco Grand Prix, flights from London to Cannes or Nice are estimated at about £8,835 to £8,895.

The passage also lists the most expensive airports for landing fees, based on the 767-400 aircraft, which is often used for private travel. The top three most expensive airports are all in Japan: Haneda Airport charges £4,559, Narita International Airport charges £3,728, and Kansai International Airport charges £3,594. Other airports in the top 10 for high landing fees include Toronto Pearson International Airport, Darwin International Airport, Bristol Airport, and La Guardia Airport in New York. Dublin Airport and Salzburg Airport also feature on the list, with Dublin in eighth place and Salzburg in tenth. These high fees reflect the exclusivity and demand for these airports among private jet travelers.

1. Katie Gallegos, from Clackamas County, Oregon, who runs Dogpatch Resort, took her dogs Cooper and Daisy to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream.
2. While Daisy took delicate licks of her ice cream, Cooper consumed his in one bite, showcasing his quick eating habits.
3. Gallegos ensures that Daisy eats first because of Cooper's tendency to eat rapidly.
4. A video of Cooper's ice cream snatch has gone viral with over seven million views.
5. Some viewers found the video of Cooper's eating habits cute and funny, while others criticized Gallegos for giving ice cream to her dogs.
6. Gallegos defended her actions by stating that Cooper is active and healthy, and she previously had a dog that lived to 19 years old and also enjoyed weekly ice cream treats.
7. She also mentioned that Daisy, being smaller, only gets a few licks of ice cream occasionally.
8. The dogs have a liking for fast food, as another video shows them at Starbucks where Cooper again quickly consumes a "pup-uccino," which Gallegos clarifies is just whipped cream without any coffee.

1. Gary Locke has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock Football Club.
2. He initially joined Kilmarnock as an assistant manager to Allan Johnston in the summer of the previous year.
3. Locke took over as interim manager when Johnston resigned at the beginning of February.
4. Since becoming interim manager, Locke has suffered only one defeat in seven matches.
5. The 41-year-old former Hearts boss has signed a three-year contract with Kilmarnock.
6. Locke will be speaking at a press conference on Friday morning following his appointment.
7. The announcement of his permanent role was formalized with a handshake with Kilmarnock's chairman, Jim Mann.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused Seminole County Elementary School of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the essential oils he wears to manage his condition. Kemp applies the oils, which are manufactured by doTERRA, to Logan's head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. Although Logan has been using the oils all year, a teacher's aide recently complained about the smell, leading to a warning from the school that the oils were distracting to other students. Kemp received a letter from the school board stating the oils had created a problem. Despite the threat of suspension, Kemp intends to continue using the oils, arguing that they have a positive impact on her son. The oils in question have scents such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood. doTERRA describes their products as "beautifully and powerfully fragrant." The Lake County School District has since clarified that they will not suspend Logan, citing the issue as a health concern.

1. A fire broke out on Wednesday afternoon at a beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons, specifically in Westhampton Beach, destroying 90 condos.
2. The fire was intense, with smoke visible from three miles away, and it caused the eventual collapse of the building. The heat from the blaze was so severe that it melted the paint on nearby structures.
3. Twelve fire crews attempted to extinguish the flames but were unable to enter the buildings due to the fire's intensity. Firefighters had to use cranes to approach the fire.
4. The complex, known as the Sandpiper, serves as a holiday home for residents from May to November.
5. Janice Sklarek, an owner of one of the apartments, described the scene as unbelievable, with flames coming out of every window.
6. The building manager, Rob Taber, who lived and worked in the complex, expressed distress as he had lost everything in the fire.
7. Witnesses reported seeing flames from a distance, and the fire chief mentioned that the wind was offshore, which helped with visibility for firefighting efforts.
8. The cause of the fire is under investigation, with one line of inquiry being that it may have started near a car parked by the complex.
